comments.comment: This class is easy, just show up, take notes, and listen. They require you to do homework but you should go for the online stuff instead of purchasing the book because it is useless and you never use it again.
Prof. Sally Ness: 1 MT 1 Final Non-cumulative. Minimal reading (only to keep up in discussion). At minimum: take notes in lecture, attend and participate in discussion.

I took the class with Prof. McMullin. She assigned 3 essays, with 1F and 1M. There is assigned readings but not really any hw besides readings and essays, I only remember having to write like a paragraph and turn it in online. She links back readings and videos we watch in class to lectures, expects a mention or 2 in your essays, and many questions on the midterm and final are based on them. In short, doing the readings, they're pretty important. Her TAs can be strict or lenient, pray on that, as they grade your 3 essays. McMullin is very much lenient herself, she gave us an extra credit opportunity for 30 free points on our 200 point midterm and even gave us the final's essay questions as take home. 

TLDR: Easy class, IF you do the readings. DO READINGS.

Class is not difficult, but the way your TA grades makes a huge difference. You need to go to lectures and all discussions, counts for like 10%. Pray that your TA is lenient, because the essay rubrics are very subjective (10 points can be docked off resulting in a B- just for "lack of persuasiveness".) Do the readings, the exams are based on them and lecture. Overall, the material is not difficult, but the grading is sooo subjective, even for the exams.
Homework, Professor was boring, exams were lame.
I had Prof. McMullin. A LOT of reading.
Took it with Dr. Nida; Go to lecture for clickers, read occasionally, and go to discussion and you should be fine, passed with an A+
Had worku nida, its an easy class but a lot of homework. Dont sit at the front of the class if youre shy

Easy with Professor Nida. 1 midterm (50 multiple choice) and 1 cumulative final (100 questions). 4 one page movie reviews, 2 two page papers, and attendance is taken through poll everywhere. Many extra credit points available.

took it with Dr. Nida this quarter, honestly he is a good professor. just do the readings because some concepts are not intuitive. 3 assignments in the entire quarter and clicker questions that are answered on a free app during lecture.

A lot of homework and reading, just go to class for poll everywhere questions. Midterm had 60 multiple choice questions with 3 extra credit multiple choice questions. (63 total) He gave 15 extra poll everywhere points to everyone so there is possibility for extra credit.

Worku Nida has a thick accent but you get used to it. He uses poll everywhere so attending lecture is kinda mandatory. We had two 2 page papers to write which you got an A on if you put any effort into them. It was a very interesting class and I would recommend.

Dr. Nida - I wouldn't say this class was free. You definitely need to read to do well on the midterms and finals since the questions are based off of the readings. However, everything else was easy and if you are diligent in not missing points by not attending lecture, answering clickers, doing the extra credit, you can easily get over a 100% in the class. The extra credit literally boosts your grade by 4%. His RMP rating is deceivingly bad but I would still recommend taking this class.

Dr Nida is a wonderful and sweet man, and obviously knows the content he's teaching, but unfortunately he can't lecture to save his life. I believe he teaches during fall and spring quarters. Attendance is done through PollEverywhere so show up to lecture for that. Otherwise if you do the readings, show up to discussion (my TA was wonderful - Breidy if you're reading this you're the best!), and do what's required you'll be okay. 3 assignments, 1 midterm, and 1 final which is only cumulative for everything covered after the midterm. There is also 10 points of extra credit. I finished with a B+ in the class and I think I could have done better if my participation grade were higher.
Just read the text book and all of the tests are multiple choice.
I got an A+ without studying that much-review the study guide and go to class, participate in discussion

Took it online with Prof Worku Nida. He does prerecorded lectures. His class consists of 2 essays (one is 2 pages long and another is 3 pages), 1 midterm and 1 final (which he gives out optional practice exams before each), and discussion is mandatory. Pretty easy A.
Had Nida, he is the best ever for this class! I loved him, easy A if u put in the work.
Easy Class. Every exam questions are on quizlet. Please always submit your work on-time and attend to all lectures if possible.

dr nida winter 2021: super interesting subject, lectures optional. never really had to study past the weekly homework "quizzes", and grading of writing assignments all depends on your ta--i got really lucky w reed who was super nice and lenient.
Had this with Professor Nida. This isn't a difficult class at all and was my first Breadth class I took at UCR. As long as you study before the exams, you should be good.

Took it with Professor Stanton and his grading policy is very straightforward. He doesn't post slides online, so if you don't attend lecture regularly, you'll most likely fail the class. Easy to follow the class but it could get really boring sometimes. Going to discussion and following the study guide helps a lot for the exams
Ok teacher, not hard and not easy. Memorization is key
The midterm and final require lots of memorizing, however, a fairly accurate study guide is given. The writing assignments and quizzes are super easy and should be an easy grade booster.

Took this course online w/ Stanton because of quarantine. I did not watch all of the pre-recorded lectures because I relied more on the textbook (which he wrote himself). The online reading quizzes were easy and directly pulled out of the textbook. The five assignments in section are really easy. Two midterms and one final, all multiple choice.

I had Professor Tsukamoto as my professor, and I had a lot of fun in class. I'm not really interested in archaeology, so I was a little hesitant taking the course, but I'm happy I did it. I will be honest though, he is incredibly difficult to understand due to his thick accent, but if you read the book he provides you, the class is incredibly easy. The quizzes are very straightforward and short, the exams are exactly what he describes them to be. My TA Johanna Najera was also super nice and she is very knowledgable on the topics that we learn. She also worked with the professor on various excavations that he went to. Overall a pretty easy and engaging class, just make sure you show up to every lecture because he asks mini quiz questions throughout every lecture.
Two midterms and a final and online chapters quizzes, overall, interesting class and if you take notes it will be easy.
So fun I loved this class with Tsukamoto and you just have to keep up on the vocab and put in a bit of effort into the exercises and you’ll be good
Took it with Professor Stanton. Very awesome professor. Very understanding. It was asynchronous and heavy on memorization. The lectures were a little boring sometimes but overall a good class.

This class is pretty lecture heavy BUT there's no exams, only writing assignments / "projects" and so it's a pretty easy class if writing is your thing. Professor Santasilia is kinda strict at times and lectures are mandatory but it's a great class

(Spring 2021 Online) Professor Stanton. Maybe it's because the course was online but it was really simple. He had pre-recorded lectures but also held lectures that were optional. I never went and I did well on my quizzes/exams just by using the resources given by him. The class itself was graded by a few assignments given during discussion, easy chapter quizzes, 2 midterms, and the final. Discussion attendance is a must. (Be prepared to pay for the website/book he uses). Again, this course was online for me so it might be different when courses are back on campus.

Easy A. Took it with Stephan James. Completely asynchronous (10-30 minute podcasts). A couple of 3-4 sentence short assignments, a presentaion (3 minutes long, it is meant to be commercial of sorts for your final project) and a final project on a language of your choice(your given multiple options on how to do it: essay, powerpoint, art peice, presentation, podcast). Discussion section was just going over key points, show up and you get participation points.

Took Professor Young Oh. 10 weekly response posts (500+ word response) and 2 response posts (100+ word response). A debate  video (group work optional; 10-30 minute video of you taking on the role of an anthropologists and debating a chosen topic). You have the choice of taking a comprehensive Final exam (multiple choice, True-false, and essay questions) or writing up a thesis (15 page summary-argumentation essay on the class). You can easily get by without the readings or videos, just familarize yourself with lecture slides. Hardest part of the class is if you try to keep up with all of the readings and videos, there are at least 10 each week.
2 midterms, one take home quiz, and one final, good teacher, but you need to study HARD! Memorization is key to passing

Took Phuoc Duong. Weekly Responses (5 -10 sentences; 10 total). 1 syllabus quiz. 1 midterm (multiple choice; 52 questions). 1 Final (multiple choice). 1 final essay(6-8 pages)(For our class he took it out and added essay questions into the final due to time constraints.)Graded for attendance to lecture. Graded for attendance to discussion section. Lectures are a bit useless since he reads straight from the slide show, but he grades for attendance. before the midterm you can get away with not doing the readings since there are only 2-3 questions about the readings in the midterm, but after the midterm he starts to heavily rely on the readings in the weekly responses. Not a whole lot of work, just tedious.

Took Professory Anthony Jerry. There is a quarter long group project. There are 4 individual parts to turn in; question section, data section, methodology section and final report; all of it worth 175 points and takes place instead of a final. discussion posts (18 total; 2paragraphs minimum) with 2 responses (1 paragraph minimum). No midterm. He posts summaries of each readings instead of having lecture, you can read these instead of the readings, much shorter and to the point if you are short for time. He really takes his time grading, so don't expect to see anything graded till the end of the quarter.

I took it with Anna Betbeze, but generally this type of art class is very subjective and no one is ever told "your drawing sucks." I got an A in the class, but you shouldn't struggle to get an A whether you're an Art major like me or not. When you register, it shows the class and studio time. It's one after the other, so you're there for nearly 3 hours. Don't get discouraged by the time, it's necessary to have a long class for art because of the activities you're doing and sometimes there will be critiques - where everyone goes around to talk about what they liked about the drawing and what could be improved/done differently. Attendance is mandatory, if you miss one class you can miss out on a lot if it was on a critique day. Your homework is 3 large drawings each week, and she gives you a theme for the drawings, it's all still life for the most part. This class does require you to buy art supplies.

(COVID ERA) I took this class with Gerald Sheffield and it was extremely easy. Art is a subjective course so you can pretty much do whatever you want in this class (as long as it pertains to the theme). Every week there's a new theme (figure, landscape, still life, etc.) and you just need to paint things based on that theme. The materials can get really pricey but Gerald was pretty lenient with whatever material you use. The online class was set up with you logging on and following Gerald's painting examples but there were also times where you explain your painting process and thoughts when you showcase and review your pieces in class. If you want an easy course without minding spending somewhere between $50-$100+ on materials then go for this class.

took online with professor conaway, assignments were pretty simple and class time was mostly her showing photographers' work as examples or us presenting the photos we took for an assignment. labs are by appointment so you don't need to go unless you need help with smth. she was really nice & class was fun and straightforward!
Super easy with Professor Charles Long. There is reading tho.

description: INTRODUCTORY WEB-BASED ART:  SITE CREATION AND NAVIGATION
INTRODUCTION TO VIDEO AND TIME-BASED EXPERIMENTATION

comments.comment: Nicole Strathman is a very chill professor. Class is not that difficult if you go to class and take notes. No homework, gave out extra credit which was to go to a museum and answer the questions, she gives out pop quizzes which are short answer(about 3-4 questions), midterm was short answer questions and a page front and back of multiple choice (midterm is easy only if you study) gotta rememeber the images she shows, final is online and she posts questions all you gotta do is answer each question using key terms and at least a page each. legit all her quizzes and tests are all on the lecture so just show up to class. sounds like a lot but its really not. good luck.

description: HISTORY OF WESTERN ART: BAROQUE TO MODERN

comments.comment: Took Spring 2021 (online) w/ Katherine Rush. Pretty easy course, just take notes and participate every once in a while. Lectures are recorded and discussions are mandatory. There's readings but you mainly need to read short articles for discussion and skim through lecture readings b/c the assignments require it. ~6 writing assignments throughout the quarter and 1 final paper (make sure to be really specific when explaining). Pretty easy class and its interesting. Prof is also really nice and understanding

description: BERLIN METROPOLIS IN LITERATURE, FILM, MUSIC, AND ART
VISUAL ART AND VISUAL THEORY AFTER 1945
JUNIOR AND SENIOR SEMINAR IN ART HISTORY
SEMINAR IN ISLAMIC ART AND CULTURE

comments.comment: Class is a remedial class. Focus on the feedback of the professor and use your essay as a standing point. The class is a S/NC so focus on getting easy point early  and not worrying on the final later on.

might be a hard class if you are not native speaker, but professor Fenton is super nice if you go to his OH and watch his pre recorded lectures. Don't bomb your essay cause those are like 75% of your grade. At the end this is only a S/NS class.

This class fail you twice or more on purposely so u can take it again before you get ready for engl 004, especially ucr English department or UC trying make money from our pocket. U only get 5 tries then they automatically move you up to engl 004. Personally I would definitely not take that class again Bc it’s just waste of time, units and dragging ur own major requirements, so I would said take “city college classes” to skip bswt 003 and English 004, so u can waive out engl 1a. Used “Assist.org” to help which city college class can transfer to ucr engl 1a. In the end, don’t waste your energy this class because bswt 003 is joke and rigged asf. I wouldn’t recommend it if ppl got place this class after taking AWPE, either place to bswt 001, 002 and 003. It just waste of energy and time investment.

description: INTRODUCTION TO HUMANITARIAN AND HEALTHCARE SERVICE

comments.comment: Very useless class. Mandatory for Biochem majors with medical emphasis. One paper on plan for medical school. Class was a rehash of BCH 95 but just with the paper.
Dingwall is the best prof for this course. Cutoffs are awesome. But dont fall behind in her coursework.
The only reason i didn't give this a 10/10 for difficulty was the pass rate was 95%

Taken with Paul Larsen. Honestly was much easier than expected. Test are fair, he tells you what will be on it. There is a lot to memorize but if you keep with it it should not be a problem. Larsen is also really funny and makes class enjoyable, would recommend recording his lectures!

I really liked P. Larsen. He was really funny which made it easy to pay attention in class. He had 5 quizzes taken during discussion so we didn't always have to go to discussion every week. We had only one midterm and the final. He recorded lectures which was really nice because he tends to talk fast. Just make sure to be on top of your stuff and you'll do well.
Medium difficulty; take it with Paul Larsen. He teaches well, gives extra credit, and curves the class as well at the end.
Dingwall was amazing and fair. Focus on her lectures to do well on the exam. Grade is determined by 8 homework assignments. Grade is determined by 1 midterm and 1 final

Took it with Dingwall and Eulgem online during Spring 2021. Tbh one of my favorite classes at UCR so far. The profs are extremely passionate and very helpful if you go to office hours. The material is a bit difficult to keep up with at first, but it is very manageable. To study for midterms, I would write out notes based off of the learning objectives. Then I would make Anki cards using my notes and the exact wording that was used on the learning objectives. Try to start memorizing pathways 2-3 days before the exams (at least).
Had it with Dr.Dingwall, she is an amazing professor but don't fall behind on the lecture notes/material

Lots of work, but Dingwall makes the class a great experience. Her and the TAs are very open to helping you, so don't hesitate to go to their office hours for help. If you put in the effort you'll definitely get that A

The instructor is super dry but the class is early in the morning which lets you get it over with early and all of the slides are there with the information to memorize and they have outline questions to help. Get the big concepts down and you'll be fine.

description: SEMINAR IN GENETICS, GENOMICS, AND BIOINFORMATICS
BIOPHOTONICS:  LASER-TISSUE INTERACTIONS AND THERAPEUTIC APPLICATIONS
SPECIAL TOPICS IN BIOMEDICAL OPTICAL IMAGING
EFFECTIVE WRITING FOR BIOENGINEERING RESEARCH PUBLICATIONS

comments.comment: Cellular basis of life, taken with Quinn McFrederick. Class itself isn't too difficult. It's biology for non-majors so no-one expects too much of you. General intro to biology course. Labs require a lab coat though, which is fun. Midterms and final aren't too bad, just study mastering biology and the previous in class material and you'll be fine.

Took the class with Maslov. Maslov only had exams, but you'll be fine even if you never went to lecture by simply studying the slides as well as the past midterms he provides for the respective midterms. Labs were easy, since you never really do anything complicated and could just follow the lab manual step by step, and most of the time, they were short and you'll be leaving early.

description: INTRODUCTION TO CELL AND MOLECULAR BIOLOGY

comments.comment: Maslov is an easy professor. Test averages 60-70
Just go to lecture and actually pay attention
I found this class to be the easiest of the series. Take Nothnagel/Martins-Green if you can. Their curve is generous and they're very nice people.

Read the book and go over posted powerpoints.  Maslov and Kaloshian post practice problems too, so go over those to get a feel of the midterm/final styles.  No need to go to class if you read the material.

I had it with Maduro -- he is doing this new system where he made ~50 videos covering the material, and instead of having lectures has the videos due semiweekly (with "clicker" quiz questions inside) and holds office hours for lecture. I actually really enjoyed it, most of my friends didn't attend lecture if it was their first class and still got A's (I got an A-). One thing to watch out for is he will try to trick you on the midterms (all multiple choice): you will read the question, immediately know the answer, and when you get the midterm back realize you read it wrong! Be sure to read each midterm question carefully, and if you are choosing "the obvious answer" read the question and think of the concept carefully. Beyond that, he is hilarious, the videos are hilarious, but the lecture/OH is a bit boring (he repeats himself... a lot). Still, most I know really struggle with Bio 5A, Maduro knows this and tries to give us as much help as possible without throwing A's at us. He'll give you every exam he's ever written (some going back to 2006 I think?), do them all! Oh, and a pro-tip I wish I discovered sooner: the video have a "view captions" tab, and most of the quiz questions (which halt the video) are discussed right after in the script, so you can look there "to confirm your answer".

This was the hardest class out of the BIOL005 series for me, as it was extremely focused on chemistry. I took it with Sarjeet Gill and Omar Akbari; Gill was a good professor but he went so fast during lecture while Akbari was the opposite and Akbari's slides were a mess. Akbari seemed like he was extremely passionate in teaching but you can be as passionate as you want and still be a not so great professor

Class was split between Katayoon Dehesh and Maneula Martins-Green. While Dehesh was a bit all over the place, her test questions were more straight-forward than MMG, whose questions are more similar to AP Bio questions.

Not hard but covers a lot of material in a short amount of time. Just stay on top of your studying and you should be fine. Had Dr. Adler and Dr. Mauck. There were 3 midterms, a final, and no homework.

Took it with Dr. Dillman and Dr. Mauck. I prefered Dillman of the two becuase kahoot really allowed you to pinpoint what you knew. Mauck had activities that layed out all the sequences though. Other than that you dont really need to go to lecture. Had 3 midterms and a final, all of which i thought were pretty straightforward. Just study outside of class, do well in discussion, and you should be good.
This class was extremely hard. Points only stemmed from quizzes, two midterms and one final. Don't mess up on any of them as it will extremely affect your grade in the end.

Took it with Dr.Gil. One of the most tedious classes. Covers lots of material, so make sure to read the book and get all the concepts down. I think we had one midterm and one final. The problems were multiple choice, but they were very specialized on the comprehension of processes and concepts.

Take Maduro's version if you can. His averages are higher, he gives a ton of his past exams with answers, and you do not have to go to class. But definitely you have to be self-motivated to do the weekly videos which count for points. His exams test for real undrstanding and he gives new questions each time so you can't just memorize the old tests. The videos are straight forward/to the point and I saved a ton of time by doing them on my own and skipping the classes. THis is totally the way an intro Bio course should be done, sitting in a class watching someone go through a bunch of powerpoints in an hour doesn't really work and Maduro gets that.
DO NOT TAKE WITH MARTINS GREENS. study the book and go to class or you wont do well.

Had Professor Ray Andasknar and Professor Alder Dilman. Dilman taught the first half, and his midterm was pretty straight forward. If you read the reading notes and looked over the notes for Dilman his exam wasn't bad. For Professor Ray it was a harder midterm because he kinda cant word things good (ex. grammar issues) but they aren't bad either. For him you're gonna need to put in more effort though. The final wasn't bad, but don't cram for the final as it was worth a lot. Overall, 5A material isn't hard you just have to make the time to study which is what gets to people.

Had Dahesh and Martins-Green. Dahesh is charismatic and made the lectures engaging. Martins-Green seems to get a bad rep, but I think she means well and really wants students to learn. Overall I didn’t find lectures to be enough and needed to read the book. Exams are multiple choice. Midterms were about the same difficulty but final had more convoluted questions imo.

Took it with Dehesh and Martins-Green (Dehesh for the 1st half, Martins-Green for the 2nd). Both use clickers in class and the questions sometimes end up being on the exams. Dehesh's exams were way more straightforward and Martins-Green's exams required slightly more analyzing (similar to AP Bio questions in high school) but were still manageable. Reading the textbook helps a lot with filling in the details because both professors go over topics very generally (especially towards the end). Personally, I found this class relatively manageable but that's most likely because I've taken gen bio courses before.
Very hard and conceptual test questions given with a very limited time frame! Wish I had more time to finish the tests! Also wish the teacher taught more material

took this class w/ professor Maduro during spring 2020, even though I enjoyed the recorded lectures and ability to earn points through them, his tests were extremely difficult for me. The tests were not similar at all with the practice exams. If you want to pass, you NEED to study, and really grasp the application of the concepts.
Maduro is picky so u have to really try to get an A average was a 54 percent for most tests and that ended up being a B
Maduro is the best professor, esp how he formats the class. His class could get difficult, but do the practice exams and that should help a ton

[COVID-19 SPRING 20] Took this class ONLINE with Ryan Joseph and Zhenbiao Yang. Both professors are very nice and passionate about their field. Joseph is an exceptional teacher and organizes his slides in a very efficient and easy to understand way. I definitely learned more from Joseph. Some of the information he teaches coincides with what you learn in Chem 1B (for the first few weeks at least). Yang is not as good in terms of clarity and presentation of information, but he will gladly answer questions and explain topics more thoroughly if need be. Both professors opted for online videos that you could watch at any time. Yang held his Zoom lecture at the scheduled time, but also uploaded said lecture online. There are two midterms and a final and it was all open book. As long as you take detailed notes from the slides, you will earn a good grade.

Took Martins-Green/Dehesh in Winter 2021. Honestly, I was struggling during the class. I barely understood what was being said, despite reading the book chapters assigned. Definitely skip. Grade is based on discussion, two midterms, and a final.

Had it with Mauck/Atkinson. Mauck is pretty good but Atkinson isn't the best lecturer as he goes on tangents and isn't very focused. The class grading is very generous as discussion is 35% of the class and its easy to get an A+. Still recommend
Heavy memorization

Avoid Chappell at all costs. This class is challenging regardless of the professor but Chappell makes it absolute hell. I've heard that Redak is still kind of hard, so keep your guard up around him too.
Avoid Chapell if he's still teaching. His tests are extremely difficult
Make sure you know everything on the notes. And I mean everything

It was incredibly difficult because there is a lot of information that you must memorize. It is a requirement for most CNAS students and some BCOE students but overall it was an interesting class, but lots to memorize!
Redak's material was hard.  Study for the final.

Had Regan/Hammond. No curve that would help your grade. Regan gets questions from the textbook. Hammond creates her own questions. Pure memorization. Hardest out of the BIOL 5 Series. Its normal to retake the class.
Much tougher than Biol005A as there is a lot much information to learn. Understanding the main ideas, trends, and applying them are key to succeeding in this course.
Extremely hard if you get Chappel
Chappell is the destroyer of GPAs.

This class is hard in general, heavy memorization and application. Everyone says to avoid Chappel but honestly hes a good teacher and his curve got me an A. Make sure you got all clicker points, and a very high grade in the lab.

Took it with Dr. Chappell. One of the hardest classes I’ve ever taken, he covers so much material during lectures and he has extremely hard clicker questions. He tends to ask questions that require a very high level of comprehension of material. Two midterms, one final. I remember scoring class average (20%) but huge curve saved us!
Had Redak, his exams are based on his lectures but will force you you to think outside the box most of the time. Trust your gut.

I thought it was harder than BIOL005A because there is a lot to memorize since most of what we learn is about animal and plant diversity. Definitely stay on top of studying/reading because it's a lot to memorize.

Took with Santiago and Campbell. The class average on the final was 57% and the curve will likely help me pass. Lab is the key to passing. Don’t slack off in lab. Heavy memorization and less application based than 5A

Took it with Redak. There's a ridiculous amount of information to memorize and his questions are messy and really test your conceptual understanding of the material. However, getting a good grade is completely doable as long as you keep up with the material. Pay attention to small details in the slides. Going to lecture helped a lot in pin pointing what would be on exams, but he mainly just reads off slides so its not completely necessary. He said he wouldn't curve, but most of my friends ended up with half a letter grade higher than expected. However, I wouldn't rely on this as I know he did not curve the quarter before I took the class.
Study the slides given in class and you will do well. I had santiago and got an A. Also make sure to do well in Lab those are easy points.
Class is not bad. However, make sure to study consistently. Also, there is a curve usually if you take the class with Santiago.

Multiple choice for all test questions. If you have Mauck, her tests are more analysis of the material rather than memorization. If you have Atkinson, his tests are more memorization than analysis - he uses questions from the practice tests sometimes or similar ones. Stephanie is a great TA - stick with her if you end up getting her. In general tho - TOPIC NOTES. They save your life.

5B was a trip. Definitely hardest of the series in terms of the amount of material you're expected to know. BUT I had Ryan Joseph who is a LEGEND for 5B. His lecture notes are really organized and structured in a very clean and organized way that made studying for this class easier and not have to scramble through slides and whatnot. He also post study questions for each lecture that are crucial for doing good on the test. This is a memorization class but his questions really helped you pinpoint what you should know for the exams as his exams were fair and reflected the study questions he posted. Rack as many points as you can in lab because if you do good in lab it really boost your overall grade. I would highly recommend Ryan Joseph for 5B as this truly is a weeder class.

Had it with Redak/Campbell Spring 2020. They were really nice and understood what everyone was going through. The class was hard as everyone made it seem - lots of memorization especially the first half. It gets easier when you get out of the animal section. You could get A's on the exams by memorizing the lectures, I didn't open the book once the entire quarter.

Took it with Meyer Summer 2020. Lectures and slides were clear and he is helpful in office hours. Meyer was also extremely fair with grading. Tests were not difficult if you studied (they were also open note because of remote learning). I thought the content was easier than Bio 5A. Lab and homework was super easy too. Grading scale: 45% Tests (15% per exam), 35% HW, 20% Lab.

(Fall 2020 Online) I gave this a 8/10 in difficulty. This class is HEAVY MEMORIZATION and there is so so so so so so so much information. It's not the professors fault honestly, it's just what this class entails. You also have to be able to build upon information. I took it with Dr. Scott Kelly. He does recorded lectures with set of notes and holds live office hours. The videos can be long and kind of boring because of his monotone voice. I recommend you read the notes before you start the videos, that way you learn and retain more during the videos. There are 2 noncumulative midterms, 3 noncumulative quizzes, and 1 cumulative final. Please take this class seriously and study at least one week before each exam or quiz. Dr. Kelly did a great job of providing "What you need to know" slides at the end of each lecture so that you can really pinpoint what to study. There is NO CURVE and NO EC. I also recommend doing well on the very first midterm as that will set the stage and also get 100% on your lab portion as that is 25% of your final grade and can really give you that boost. I somehow scraped by with a B.
Easiest of the bio 5 series
Easiest in the series, just keep up with it. Make sure to know the notes at least
Pretty easy stuff.  Know the calculations portion.  Nunney and Rafferty were pretty good.
Easiest of the series. Took with Rafferty and Nunney. Just make sure you study a lot of people get cocky and end up doing poorly on the 2nd midterm and final because of it.
Took Nunney and Rafferty (not sure about spelling) Keep up with the lectures and you should be fine.

Had Prof. Rankin (teaches first 5 weeks/Ecology), and Prof. Stouthamer (teaches last 5 weeks/Evolution). Overall, wasn't all that bad. We had three tests total; two midterms and a final. All were multiple choice. Rankin's portion was slightly harder because we had to analyze graphs and make sure to know when to apply certain formulas (but she always gave us a formula bank so that was good!). Stouthamer's portion was -personally- a bit more boring, but if you study his slides you'll get by alright. Pulled a B+ but I believe an A is definitely doable. Lab portions are easy.

I think I got a relatively bad grade but I really neglected studying for this course bc it really is one of those you can get away with skipping lecture and cramming with. I took it with Michael Anderson/Bai-Lian Li.

Relatively easy class. Took it with Rafferty/Degnan. Rafferty content is super easy while Degnan is much more difficult and dense. No books required, only clickers. Grades are about 70% exams, 10% clicker, 20% lab. Two midterms, both worth 10-15%. Final is a big chunk being about 45%. Lab portion super easy.

Huge step down from BIOL 005B. Studying for this class is much easier than it was for BIOL 005B. For the lab portion, your grade in lab is highly dependent on participation and this final  group project. The group project is pretty easy as long as you have a good group and an easy project. The exams were not too difficult to study for, but for the final exam, make sure to study the lab portion because there will be 10 questions from the lab portion that is not covered in lecture.

Only reason why I gave this such a high difficulty is because the professors are complete assholes when it comes to grading for 5C. Please for the love of everything do not take Prof. Ponisio, this quarter was hell in 5C cause of her and her lying and unprofessionalism. Prof Hansen for Evolution was more understanding and more content on her notes so studying for her part of the class was easier. 5C material is the easiest of the series and the professors know that students push this class on the backburner so they make the grading scale harder than of 5B and 5A. If you study consistently then you can easily get an A, but I studied the night before the exams and walked out with a B.
Not a hard class, but don’t neglect it, as information piles on fast. 4 tests so you do have tests often, but material is not cumulative so its not too bad

Genetics and evolution. Pretty digestible concepts and easy math. If you took AP Bio, this is review. Very cram-worthy considering midterms (2) and the final were taken almost directly from the slides. Never attended lecture and did fine. Barry Li and Ring Carde.

description: HEADLINES IN THE HISTORY OF LIFE

comments.comment: Equivalent to BIOL05LA, so you won't need to take BIOL05LA if you take this class. If you're taking this class, you most likely won't have a choice in who you get in terms of professor and TA. Useful class since it teaches you the basics in lab techniques and equipment. Be prepared to learn beyond what you may expect in regular biology. At the end of the class, students are expected to give a presentation about their project and a paper about the same project (project would be given to you by professors in the class; you will understand what this means when you get to that point in the class).

Took with Alex Cortez, but most of the grading is done by the TA, which, depending on how picky they are, can make or break your grade in the class. Better lab experience than BIOL 05LA, but a lot of work for a 2 unit class.

One of the hardest classes I've taken at UCR...a lot of work for a 2 unit class. Took a lot time that could've been used to study for other hard classes. Save yourself the time and take BIOL05LA instead.
As long as you do the homework and understand it well, you should be fine. The best way to succeed in this class is by doing the problems over and over again until you understand it.

My professor was Alex Cortez. The first half of the course isn't too bad, but sometimes the lab writeups take some time to do. This class is kind of like a biotechnology/intro to research stuff class since you do PCR and gel electrophoresis a lot. Just make sure to understand the concepts since the midterm and final is all application. People generally do bad on the midterm, but better on the final. The second half of the course was focused on a research project for an actual research lab, where you had to really understand the experimental design and do a lab report and presentation. This class is good experience for those interested in research.
Lots of work in the class.  Heavily dependent on how hard your TA is.

One of the best classes on campus!! Yes, its hard work and sleepless nights and a class full of confused faces but I believe this class has shaped me into the person I am today. If ur concerned about ur GPA don't take this class.

Had Burnette. I love the man in that he's super nice and you can tell he really likes what he teaches. Provides a lot of advice and is great at answering questions. Just pay attention in class and read the experiment PDFs he provides.

Great class if you're into research. Read and take notes of material before each class. Had Dr. Chetty and she's alright. Huge curve at the end of the quarter. I finished off with a B- and my grade went to an A- but I'm not sure if it is because we took it online during a pandemic or if grades are usually curved.

As long as you kind of pay attention during notes/studying the slides on your own, you will likely pass this class. Very little study required even for an A if you are good at memorizing facts/anatomy.

I have a bit of a bad taste from this class but it I took it because it was supposed to be an easy A. Class is more for younger people that don't have much sexual education from classes and personal experience. TA made discussion an absolute chore to get through. I got an A but I realized a little too late that I didn't need to work that hard to get it. LOTS of fluffer points from discussions, quizzes, and assignments.

Professor Kahn was pretty good. The class was pretty interesting even though plenty of people seemed uncomfortable every moment we were in discussion. The exams were open note and I did well overall. Would recommend to most.
Took this during Fall 2020 (virtual), asynchronous lectures, weekly mandatory discussion. open note quizzes, midterm, and final. Only 2 assignments and they were pretty straightforward,

Took this class during covid with Professor Kahn. I am giving the class a 4 because even though the assignments, exams, and everything was easy you needed virtually all of the points to actually get an A. She claims that she doesn't curve the class at all. The class was out of 500 points and there wasn't any homework. You can really not mess up on any assignment or there goes your A.

description: INTRODUCTION TO CELL AND MOLECULAR BIOLOGY LABORATORY

comments.comment: Quizzes are easy and short multiple choice questions.  Lab exercise grades depend on pickiness of TA.  Final sucked hard--it had material that wasn't learned in class.  Whoever wrote it didn't have good English skills either.
Overall not too hard. Actually try on the worksheets and read the lab manual before each lab and you should be fine. Final is difficult and dropped me 6% but the curve brought me back up to an A.
Overall, the labs were easy but my TA was too harsh on grading. Final was also really focused on the expected results per lab.

The lab portion itself is easy. You do worksheets in the class and the material correlates a lot to lecture so it helps with the learning process. The prelab quiz are really easy and a quick skim though the lab manual you can get full credit on those quizzes. For the 3 major quizzes thought the quarter, really focus on the results and the procedures and look over the worksheets and you will be good. This quarter (Fall 2019) I thought the lab final was cake, as it was just all the worksheets and the practice exam that were on the exam, but do study if you want high grade. I think they might've change the 5LA final because people previous quarters told me it was very difficult and stuff on it wasn't learned, but that wasn't the case this quarter.

Labs are easy, but my TA graded harshly and people rarely got full credit on assignments. Worksheets are straightforward and the 3 bigger quizzes emphasized results. I’d study learning objectives, review results and the reasoning, not many calculations or stuff about procedure. Overall, I was more worried about my lab grade than the actual class grade which is lame.

Legitimately not that hard.  Many complain Maslov doesn't really teach but learning genetics is mostly rote memorization and practice.  You're just getting the basic principles down.  He provides lots of practice problems and old exams, so if you go through those and understand the problems, you're guaranteed an A.

Had David Nelson for this class. His lectures are useful, but it is very important to read the book in order to do well, as he takes a lot of concepts from the book for his exams. Generous curve, so if you study hard you should be able to get an A.

Had Gachomo for the first half and her teaching consists of reading the slides while the midterms consists of material we rarely went over. Her midterms not only cheated our time but she would have so many questions that were impossible for many students to finish in the time allotted. Bachant was an amazing professor in the second half. Definitely understood the struggle of the students and thoroughly went through the material. The material itself isn't that hard except that if you miss a part then it gets slightly confusing.

Took with Dr. Arthur Jia Spring 2021. AMAZING professor he truly cares for his students and wants you to do well. Ample opportunities for office hours and midterm review. HOWEVER, his two midterms were short answer, fair, and closed book. Final was 25 mc closed book. Class is graded on a class scale (20-25% get A's etc.)
Do not take this for an easy A

While the material is generally pretty simple for an Upper div bio class, there is a lot to memorize and the class is test heavy, with 2 midterms, 2 practicals, quiz every week, and a final. Not bad but if all your looking for is an easy A look elsewhere.

I don't think the material was hard but it was having Dr.Chen as a professor. He can get off track easily and disorganized. He said he is changing the class layout next time he teaches because he found out that his class correlates with BIOL 121 a little too much.

Chen and Jin were a little difficult to understand (accents). Jin's midterm had some stuff we covered in the second half rather than the first. Chen gives you possible things that will be covered on the final but not all of it will appear. The good thing is that you can bring in a full sized cheat sheet for the final. The curve was legendary.
The class is not easy. It is difficult and time intensive. Also, there is barely any curve in this class with Hailing Jin, so avoid taking the class with her.
nice guy, talks slow, watch out for case studies in lecture

I had Anderson. Funny guy, laid back. Class was boring at times, but he showed a lot of videos. His exams sometimes require notes taken from his lectures. His slides are mostly pictures so you kinda have to go to know what he says. Avrg for midterms ~85%
took it with Nicole Rafferty. She is a sweetheart. The lectures are alright and her tests were straightforward. You should be as long as you go over the lecture notes.
Relatively easy class, open note exams, just requires regular studying

Straightforward and a little difficult because memorization of slides and stuff is somewhat required. Good curve at the end of the class. Koenig and Chris are very nice and lab is simple as long as you pay attention to what is said.

This class is not difficult. However, Koenig is very lackluster at teaching. The lectures themselves are not very useful in getting a good grade in the course. But, the subject itself is very interesting.
Take with Roper

This class was easy with Hsiao. Just focus on objectives and HW. Go to office hours and he'll tell you the extent of what he wants you to know. Second exam is the hardest so don't let your guard down. 100 pts extra credit available and a few % curve at the end.
The class is not difficult. Roper is not very good at lecturing and the class is heavy on memorization. There is barely any curve at the end of the course.
Extremely easy upper division class; took with Woodard; covers insect behavior and there are only 8 quizzes and no midterm or final exam

Woodard is the best! She's pretty sensitive to students' hardships and appreciates feedback. During remote learning, she did away with all exams, and focused on weekly quizzes/assignments, an insect picture collection, and a virtual presentation that were all WAY less stressful than they sound.

description: SEMINAR IN GENETICS, GENOMICS, AND BIOINFORMATICS
CALIFORNIA'S CORNUCOPIA: FOOD FROM THE FIELD TO YOUR TABLE

comments.comment: Do not take this for an easy A

While the material is generally pretty simple for an Upper div bio class, there is a lot to memorize and the class is test heavy, with 2 midterms, 2 practicals, quiz every week, and a final. Not bad but if all your looking for is an easy A look elsewhere.

description: PRODUCT DESIGN AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP FOR AGRICULTURAL AND BIOLOGICAL APPLICATIONS
SEMINAR IN GENETICS, GENOMICS, AND BIOINFORMATICS

comments.comment: The final is so hard that it is majorly curved.

Took it with Ivy Zhang! At first I thought it’d be hard because I’ve heard about the previous professor but she’s completely different. It’s helpful to go to all the lectures because she explains pretty thoroughly. She also does Poll Everywhere so might as well go to class. She does online homework but you have unlimited tries, and there’s also online quizzes but the quesrions mostly online. Midterm was fairly easy, as long as you keep up with your stuff and GO TO DISCUSSION, it really helps!

No one has no clue what's going on in this class. Just do your homework. Lectures don't help since they are on the homework due the week before. Your TA is your best bet in learning anything. Average grade for the final was 55%
Samuelson is hard to keep up with sometimes. Material gets hard after the midterm. Everyone fails the final but it is curved.

[COVID-19 ERA] Took this class with Naman Desai, it wasn't really too useful too be honest. The professor was passionate about his subject and really understanding towards the students during this difficult time. But in that process unfortunately students had to suffer through recorded lectures and a subpar standard of teaching. My TA (Arthur Hou) wasn't much of a help either which only added to the stress of this class. I wish this class was in-person so I could've fully understood these concepts as accounting is an extremely important and useful subject.

Took it during COVID. I felt that bc of how people were getting adjusted, this class just.... was not the class to take. Taking the class, it felt like it isn't something you can reliably teach online. Props to the teacher for being positive and continuing but it just felt like no communications most of the time. Definitely not recommend during online learning.

I took it with Naman Desai winter 2021. Class was asynchronous with optional zoom lectures on thursday. Two exams and about 7 or so quizzes total. Not the most organized class tbh but just go over the practice problems from the recordings and you'll be good to go.

I took this class during winter 2021 when classes were online with Naman Desai. This is probably the worst class I have ever taken. The midterm and exam weren't too difficult. Honestly, if you just find random quizlets with accounting questions and use those to study, chances are that you'll see similar questions on his exams. The prof doesn't really teach - he just shows you how to do textbook problems without explaining anything. He assigned us weekly quizzes, but I didn't find them that useful. They only showed us what types of questions he was going to give us on the exams. He also didn't give us a practice midterm or final which I thought was inconsiderate, considering we were online and he wasn't that good of a professor. The TAs were also barely useful. They would just upload videos explaining the answers to quizzes, but those explanations weren't that good in my opinion. I think that this class was manageable, but not a good experience.
Barry Mishra is a horrible professor. He steals lectures from other professors and does not care about students. Basically self teach

I had Mishra and he was alright. tuesdays were asynchronous lectures and thursdays were synchronous but not mandatory. the asynchronous lectures were the most helpful because the practice problems he went over were the same format as test questions. the material was pretty hard tbh but if you're willing to study and do practice questions it should be manageable.

I had Corrine Knight. 4 books needed for this class but they weren't expensive. 4 essays in total: first was easy, second was alright but a bit hard, third was hard, and fourth was easy for me. Quizzes were given randomly and sometimes in the middle of lecture, so go to class on time. Only one midterm and all questions come from quizzes so it's easy. Two presentations (one video pres.) but they're pretty simple. TAs can be a bit strict in grading essays so try to get feedback from them.
Be prepared to do the most for this class just to get a passing grade. The essays are very time consuming and are scrutinized by the TA's

I took this Winter 2019 (i think). TAs grades based on the syllabus the professor gives but the feedback will always be ~2-3 week slate and by then you will have to start on your next essay. What the professor says to do and what the TA says tend to be different AND the TA's have to give 3 essays from each of their discussion to the professor to be graded. 
One incident where a student had an A paper but the professor graded it to a C paper because the tone of her essay wasn't professional enough but the TA said it was perfectly fine. The first midterm is really easy because it's all lecture-based but the final is a timed write and basically feels kind of like an AP Lang/Lit timed write.
There are around 4 essays total. Just don't take it with other heavy writing business courses

I had it with Acker and it was an easy class for me, someone who sucks at English. There's three main assignments and a project. The textbook is also really helpful and there's a required workshop course you have to enroll in (0.5 units). Before every assignment (except the final paper), you have to go to this workshop. Overall, this class is definitely not a stress inducer.

I took it with Rich Yueh. One of the best business professors you'll have imo. He's new to UCR but he knows his stuff and actually relates to us. I will admit, lectures were boring every now and then, but he had a good sense of humor that made up for it and the material was pretty easy to understand. He's really nice and accommodating, and goes the extra mile for students. Posts slides on iLearn but they're not that comprehensive, so you need to go to lecture for a more detailed understanding of the material. Five homework assignments but were super easy and quizzes given in lecture every other week, no midterm or final. No book needed for this class. Overall, a fun, easy class with a great professor.

Class is really easy, Professor Rich is really awesome. No book was needed because he said he knows college is expensive. Material is really easy, but if you have no coding experience the latter half of the class might be difficult for you because you have 2 assignments that require you to know Python

Professor Rich is probably one of the best professors UCR has to offer. The final project requires coding so if coding isn't your thing then oof. Overall, I enjoyed this class a lot and I was bummed that it had to end.

Lectures are a waste of time, but go after the 1st midterm they take attendance. When doing your reading notes do it in this format: summary, pro/con analysis, sprinkle in a few buzzwords from the book that Jasso hasn't reviewed yet, throw in a personal reference in your life that is a real world example, and then conclude it with how you could use the concept in your future life.
Reading Notes are a pain. Get started on your marketing plan early. Tests aren’t too bad

I took it with Kamvar Farahbod. This class isn't too hard to be honest. Homework usually had 4 to 7 questions and lectures were super boring because he reads off the slides. The slides are posted on iLearn but aren't always easy to understand imo, so I highly recommend buying the book because it teaches you the material better than he does. Doesn't always take attendance but might do so if he feels that less people come to lectures. Quizzes are given in discussion every week, so definitely attend. One midterm and one final; midterm had 35 questions (i think) on chapters 1-4 and final is on last four chapters. Overall, an okay class and you'll likely get a B or an A.
All the learning comes from the discussion. Heavy curve in the midterm and final
Professor is super boring but the homework and tests are not that bad.

I had Prof. Turcic and watching lecture and looking over the slides is a must. This course is new content for most people so set aside extra time to digest the info. However, once you understand it it is actually pretty easy concepts to grasp. He also lets you take your homework and exams with unlimited attempts, but you don't get your score until the deadline passes.

Took with Adem Orsdemir W21, fully asynchronous - 20-40min each lecture, released during official class time sharp, attendance taken via simple quizzes on lecture material. He teaches materials well, but it would definitely help if you have an interest in it beforehand and you need to get used to his accent. Very understanding, allowed midterm retake and drops lowest homework.

Took it with Kyle Ingram. I feel like the professor made this class harder than it needed to be tbh. Weekly readings assigned but they weren't too long. 4 randomly assigned quizzes in total, but the fourth quiz was basically showing up to the case competition presentation for credit. Quizzes were multiple choice and short answer, but were hard because the TAs were harsh graders. In fact, there was some grading discrepancy since one TA graded easier than other TAs. The prof. posts lectures on iLearn but you should still go anyway. One group project presentation and term paper assigned too. Discussion was useless imo but go for attendance. You don't need the textbook for this class but buy it if you don't understand the class material. Overall, not easy to get an A in this class.

Professor Ingram is no longer teaching the course but he gave 4 random quizzes worth 10% of the overall grade each. They are pretty difficult because he does not say when they are going to be and what they are about. So always review before lecture! The last quiz was free because you just vote on the group presentations. The group project is not that bad but it depends on how motivated your group members are. Make friends with your TA because they grade your term paper.
You need to buy a new book for the online code.
Wasn't too wild but professor Woody Liao is extremely difficult to understand. Unfortunately he isn't great with technology either. A lot of self-learning was done in that class.
Took with Raveendran online Spring 2021. Super easy course, some busy work but insanely doable. Consider her as your professor as opposed to Jasso or Weigel if you don't like suffering

description: INTRODUCTION TO DATA MINING AND VISUAL  ANALYTICS

comments.comment: Took with Md, insanely easy course. Had a group project, 4 labs that included excel, tableau, and Azure, 2 writing assignments (super easy), and midterm + final. The only way to fail this course is to literally not do your work.

Dr. Linda Penas is very nice and a pretty good instructor, though she has a tendency to just read off of her slides. For Spring 2020 (everything online), she only uploaded lecture slides that had material that would be on the exams (1 midterm, 1 final). There is also a weekly lab using Minitab 19, and it is really easy. The material is mostly just different procedures/concepts of statistics used in business and manufacturing situations to determine quality of products/processes. Equations are WAY easier than in most statistics classes and you are allowed to make a "cheat sheet" for exams so you don't really have to memorize any. DEFINITELY useful for Business majors; a bit less useful for Statistics majors/minors in terms of material we will use someday, but it's good for seeing how to apply statistics in real life.

description: INVESTMENTS: SECURITY ANALYSIS AND PORTFOLIO MANAGEMENT
BANKS AND RISKS OF FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS

comments.comment: [COVID-19] I took this class with Ye Li and it was honestly a really good class. At first, it was annoying that he sends out about 5 emails reminding you to do the web assignment before the first lecture (basically a ~15 minute survey for every class that relates to the lesson - he collects the students' stats to present in class). The professor is pretty lenient with the web assignments being submitted a little bit late, but that's not the case for the write ups. In the class besides the web assignments, there are 5 write-ups (with assigned readings ranging from like 5 to 15 pages, a big one being 30ish) in total that you need to do out of 8 offered in 10 weeks. The first two write ups (counted as 1) is with a randomly assigned group and was 600 words each. The rest, you are free to chose as long as you have done 5. There's no midterm and only a final - the final you have the option to go solo or choose a partner/have the professor choose one for you. The final is about a case study with 6 questions and all he tells you is that you have to use class concepts for it. You have 5 days to complete it and it had a word limit of 2000. The professor is great, he makes every topic interesting and has a lot of opportunities for extra credit throughout the quarter. Should basically be a pretty easy A class as long as you make the effort to do the web assignments and write ups. They're due every Thursday but if you turn it in the Sunday before, you get an extra credit point added to your score. I'd really recommend this class as an elective! My concentration is IS and this was definitely one of the easier classes I've taken and it was genuinely a good class.

Professor Ye is amazing and the class is really interesting. Your grade is based on 4 write-ups (you can pick from out of 8 topics), participation, and a final. The class isn't hard at all if you spend time doing the readings and listen in class.

This class with Haibo Liu is a really fun class about entrepreneurship. It mainly consist of a midterm presentation, a final presentation, a take home final, and participation credit. Doing the bare minimum and showing interest can get you a good grade in this class.

Took it with Alcaraz, not really hard, just beyond annoying that 30% of your grade is a group project and presentation in a pandemic. the prof also has attendance and participation as about 25% of the grade, and he’s never clear as to how those are calculated considering he said attendance wasn’t mandatory at the beginning of the quarter

Fall 2020 (online b/c Covid); Raj Sign taught this. If you have Raj as a professor (like in 107) then you will know the format. You will have a group project that is due at the end of the lecture week. The course materials itself aren't really hard and all of what he teaches are on the lecture slide. You can buy the book but tbh I'm not sure it's beneficial to learning. If you are a person who needs the book copy, just buy a pdf of it (usu. around $20 if you know where to look or maybe even free). You have 2 quizzes that are unannounced and will tell you about them when the time comes. There are 2 exams (open-book)and 1 final. There is HW and it's better if you do them as you finish the chapters. The HW is due at the end of the week 10

Fall 2020 (online b/c Covid); Raj Sign taught this. If you have Raj as a professor (like in 107) then you will know the format. You will have a group project that is due at the end of the lecture week. The course materials itself aren't really hard and all of what he teaches are on the lecture slide. You can buy the book but tbh I'm not sure it's beneficial to learning. If you are a person who needs the book copy, just buy a pdf of it (usu. around $20 if you know where to look or maybe even free). You have 2 quizzes that are unannounced and will tell you about them when the time comes. There are 2 exams (open-book)and 1 final. There is HW and it's better if you do them as you finish the chapters. The HW is due at the end of the week 10

description: FEDERAL TAXATION FOR CORPORATIONS, PARTNERSHIPS, ESTATES, AND TRUSTS

comments.comment: [COVID-19] Had Kan Wang after taking 171 last quarter with him as well. Pretty easy class and it has been in the same format for both. The class is mainly asynchronous with 2 live sessions - one on the first day and another around week 3. One midterm and one final (noncumulative) with most questions from the textbook and a few made by him based on the homework. There are about 4 homework assignments spread out evenly, so make sure to start a little earlier. He has extended one homework before due to some students being unable to install Microsoft Office software properly, but be reasonable and don't start the day before it's due and ask for an extension lol. Two out of four were using Microsoft Access. The last homework is always a small research paper where you have to explain a concept (for this class it was the difference between relational databases and NoSQL). Pretty easy class if you just do the work.

Took with Underhill, insanely easy professor that accomodates and understands his students. Just do the work, most of it is guided and not hard at all. The only reason you fail this course at all is because you decided to do all your work the day it was due (all our work was due last day of week 10 btw).

description: CHASS F1RST FINE ARTS COURSE: MEDIA AND CULTURAL STUDIES

comments.comment: Bachant is a terrific prof.  He provides all you need to know in his slides and supplementals.  The final was harder than the material from the first two midterms though.  Don't expect a huge curve since averages on midterms were 77-80%.

Took it with Bachant. Cool dude, but its a hard class. He gave us supplementals for the lectures and they are REALLY useful. Tests seem impossible at first, but they make sense as you read it a couple of times more.

This class is very interesting. Santhakumar was a great professor. She gives practice exams, clarifying slides, etc. She also gave a huge curve at the end of the course, so it is not hard to get a high grade in this class.

No homework, but there is a lot of material to go over, especially post midterm. Make sure you are on top of all the material, because it’s honestly a bit too much to cram right before the exam. Class is was really interesting though!
Very interesting class; study regularly and it will be easy to do well

First half I had Dr.Anderson, very straightforward guy. Even when he "tries" to trick you, its not difficult at all. Just lots of material as any upper div bio class. His average was around 67
Second half was with Dr. Hongdian. He has a rep for teaching the more dense/confusing stuff, but its not that bad at all. Just go to class so you can understand what the diagrams mean - its really straightforward if you attend his lecture and  listen/write what he says.
The discussion section requires a brain anatomy practicum so study hard for that one.
Class is not hard and exams are open note; there is a small curve ; highly recommend taking it in the summer

Online exams were no back-tracking, but it wasn't bad. Very straightforward questions, and Dr. Fiacco had lecture outlines that were really helpful when studying. Really enjoyed this class overall! :)

3 exams. not cumulative. I took it with professor Dr.Fiacco and he was incredible! Provides lecture notes himself. Study those for the test AND study the pictures of brain slices presented in class if he talks about those regions in his notes. tbh lots of material but if yeah neuro nerds this class is for you

description: CELLULAR NEUROSCIENCE: MEMBRANE AND SYNAPTIC PHENOMENA

comments.comment:
For Michael Adams, JUST AVOID HIM AT ALL COST. Class averages were always around 50%. If you are not a NURO major, I would not even take this class AT ALL. Studying is super difficult for his class because his slides are blank and refers to outside articles.

For Cho, he is a great professor for this class and only teaches the most important things in NURO. I would take him, again, if you are a NURO major and need this course.

Michael Adams; Lab reports are graded by TAs and it was fairly easy. As long as you answer the questions on the lab manual and explain the figures, you should be fine. Adams is very lenient when it comes to extensions. He extended all of the lab reports with no questions, just ask! Nice man, but very monotoned.
Studying at least once a day three times a week helped.

With professor Curras during covid. She is horrible. Does not teach in zoom, instead, she posts a lot of lectures that actually have a due date, so you have to watch it before the deadline otherwise it closes. She requires both yuja and a lockdown browser. She does not make accommodations

Took it over the summer with Professor Kurt Spurgin and it was pretty easy going. Questions are straight from notes/slides. Dont need a book and no discussion so that was great. Lots of info but memorizing is enough for this course, averages for his were around 70-75 so pretty high

description: COMPUTATIONAL NEUROSCIENCE LABORATORY: INTRODUCTION TO BRAIN MODELING TECHNIQUES

comments.comment: A+ lecturer, but the multiple choice on the exams will leave you praying to any and all gods you can think of.

2 MT's that aren't cumulative and a final that is. 7 quizzes in discussion and you present a research article in either weeks 8,9,10. First half will be easy, but the second half the information becomes a lot more difficult. MT2 was extremely difficult.

description: SEMINAR IN CELL, MOLECULAR, AND DEVELOPMENTAL BIOLOGY

comments.comment: For Dr. Wu, exams are open note. Abuse the hell out of that for an easy A

description: PRODUCT DESIGN AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP FOR AGRICULTURAL AND BIOLOGICAL APPLICATIONS
ADVANCED AIR POLLUTION CONTROL AND ENGINEERING
QUANTITATIVE ANALYSIS OF UPSTREAM PROCESSES IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
COLLOQUIUM IN CHEMICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING

comments.comment: Not as easy as 1A but it's not too hard. As always just know your stuff
Had Prof Mueller.  If you read the book, going to class is optional.  Practice homework problems and know concepts in great detail.  Final exam is difficult.
Sort of easier than 1A. Jason Cheng is a really good professor and funny at times. A lot of concepts are taught so go to lectures. I had clicker so you might too.
Took with Quan Cheng. If you understand how to use formulas and have a good TA it's not that bad of a class, but Cheng does not explain anything at all.

Had Prof Davies. His lectures were boring (nice accent though) and basically annotates his slides. Had 2 midterms and they were both hard (class average was low). He uses PollEverywhere for participation and Smartwork for homework.

Took it with Quan Cheng. He explained everything thoroughly. Just go over the questions during lecture, clicker questions, and do the Extra Homework since some of the questions on the exam stem from that. Overall, this class was not that hard.

Had Yinsheng Wang, not a bad professor by any means, but his exams are hit or miss, either really easy or ridiculously hard. Material itself isn't too bad to grasp, just make sure to understand the homework. Best way to get an A though is to read the textbook before lecture to get a grasp of the material ahead of time.

Had Dr. Chang and he's honestly really boring and its more worthwhile to read the book than to listen to his lectures. He has clickers so you're forced to go to class but as long as you do enough of them then you could honestly just go for the clicker and then just ditch. Overall CHEM001B isn't bad but it's a little more difficult than CHEM001A. I heard from my upperclassman friends that it's the hardest in the CHEM001 series, but we'll see. Just review the end of chapter problems, do the practice midterm, review the clicker questions, and the homework before the midterms/final and you'll be set! BTW he gives a lot of extra credit opportunities.
Not very hard, but make sure you do plenty of practice problems to prepare for exams; also David Hill is one of the tougher chemistry professors

Going to lecture is useless if you have Quan Cheng. A great guy, but he doesn't know how to utilize his time. I just stayed in the back and left after the clicker questions. Go over his practice tests! He copies and pastes some questions into the test and it's just good practice if you don't go to lecture.
Took it with Cheng and the midterms and final were super easy because they were mainly based off of the practice exams and the homework.

Had Cheng. Exams are straightforward and should be easy if you study the stuff he gives you: clicker, hw, practice exams, back of book practice problems. The stuff shows up on exams. His class breakdown is VERY forgiving. Lots of opportunities to earn extra points. Got a C- on first midterm, but was able to make up those points and get an A in the end.

Had Proff Zhao. Chem1B is very mathematical, lots of equations and solving word problems. As long as you know how to use equations given, you’ll be fine. Zhao is a pretty good teacher, would recommend his class.
I had Dr. Linlin Zhao. Great professor, easy to understand, pretty good policies in syllabus. 2 midterms, final. Content not too difficult.

[COVID-19 SPRING 20] I had this class ONLINE with Linlin Zhao. Attending the Zoom lecture was recommended and he occasionally tossed in some clicker questions to reward those who actively attended. Chem 1B builds off of the information you learned in Chem 1A so it's good to brush up on some of those topics. Like others are saying, this class is a lot of equations and plugging and chugging. The word problems are tricky too. Each chapter was a new concept for me, so it took me a while (and a lot of Khan Academy...) to fully understand the concepts and how the equations worked. Reading the textbook is extremely helpful and he bases most of his exam questions off of what he teaches on the slides. Zhao presents his information pretty thoroughly and takes the time to help students who are stuck. This class moves fairly quickly, so understanding all of the concepts is vital to earning a good grade. Unfortunately, the exams are all closed book and proctored. Clicker questions (20%), discussion points (10%), and homework (20%) make up 50% of the grade (as well as potential bonus points). For us, the homework had unlimited tries and there was no penalty for wrong answers. There are 2 midterms (10% each) and a final (30%). The exams aren't curved (I think), but the final class grade is based on a curve. Overall, I enjoyed this class a lot and I recommend taking it with Zhao!

I took it with Prof. Tim Su and he was amazing. I still got not so good grades on midterms and exams (like Ds lmfao) and thanks to his generous grading ended with a B+. He was an amazing prof as he really cared about his students. I would definitely suggest taking Chem 1B with him if you can
It's all equilibrium, once you understand it it's no problem
Eichler doesn't curve. Go to class--he doesn't really teach the book.
Jiang was chill but no curve :(
Easier than CHEM001B. Jiang is fair, though no curve. Lots of clickers and unlimited attempts (no penalty) on HW. Midterms look like clickers and practice exams.
The early two chapters about acids and bases are the toughest in the course and the difficulty drops off as you move through the course.
Professor Min Xue was extremely fair. His exams were all similar to the homework and study guides he put out for us. Gives out a lot of bonus points as well

Class was pretty easy once you can see the patterns to the problems. Jiang is great, clickers and practice exams similar to actual exam. You almost have to learn to do the types of calculations for clickers on the fly, but they are fair enough
Had Ming Tang. Kinda hard to follow at times. Midterms and final are nothing like the practice versions. Read the book

Took it Dr. Eichler, a very fair professor and makes lectures fun to attend. I thought it was easier than CHEM001B just because some were stuff that we learned in previous chem classes. He offers a lot of extra credit and clicker questions and iLearn quizzes (which are worth more than midterms). His exams have free response questions which are harder than multiple choice questions so look out for those.
Dr. Eichler is a good professor and offers a lot of extra credit. I would recommend him. However, he does do mc AND frqs for his midterms and final.
Easiest of the series. Jiang was fair. Exams resembled clickers and practice exams. Extra credit is available but only if you get really high clicker and homework scores

Had Eichler. He's a good lecturer, but he had us do this "creative exercise" where you had to write 10 statements about a certain chemical situation and most of your statements had to come from the material you just learned (which sounds easy until you actually do it). His midterms were not anything like other professor's midterms that I'm used to. Each exam has about half your points in free-response. Final had some curve ball questions -- make sure you know your material from past chem classes in the gen chem series...

I took it with Ming Lee Tang and the class was...strange. Discussions are only quiz-based and none of the material from lecture really gets retaught in discussion. Midterms and the Final are pretty tough and under a normal grading scale, I believe around 60-70% of the class would have failed. She's not a very approachable teacher and the same goes for the TAs. Luckily, she's not a cruel professor and curved the class so that the average student got a B. For reference, class averages for the midterms and final were around D-F range. I got above average twice(about 1-3 points above) and below average once(1 point below), and I got a B+ in the class. Tang's class is really a tossup

Had Ming Lee Tang. Decent lecturer, but her exams were DIFFICULT. practice midterms did not reflect the difficulty at all and no amount of studying could have properly prepared me. Got a low C on both midterms and a D on the final, but the curve brought me up to an A so there's that.

Had Professor Harman. Uses smartwork which is very good resource for studying for the final and midterms. It was his first time teaching 1C and so it wasn't the best but better than Hill lol, but still he was a good lecturer and made me want to go to class and pay attention. If you read/ skim the book (for the conceptual questions) and do calculations similar to the ones on the homework, you can get good scores on midterms. Final he repeated questions from midterms so do go to office hours and TA office hours to see your exam and review the ones missed. 1C material isn't hard but the chapter on acid and base and its equilibria was I thought the hardest. Easier than 1B though imo.
i have no problem with how test heavy the grades are but i really hate how the professor teaches in his lectures.

Had Eichler (think that's how he spells it). This was my easy class for the quarter so I was able to kinda neglect it and pass but it got pretty tough so that's how I ended up with like a C in the class. Also, c'mon fellas... his jokes are funny stop trashing on him for it

Took it with Jiang. Highly recommend not taking with Jiang if you don't already have experience with gen chem (ex: taking a year of chem in high school/ap chem) because he can tend to be very conceptual instead of mathematical (and the midterms are mathematical). The poll/clicker questions can be pretty difficult because he doesn't really teach them beforehand so you're kind of learning as you go. The homework can also be frustrating because in the later chapters he doesn't do a lot of practice problems that are similar to what's on the homework. The midterms are pretty ok as long as you review the quizzes, poll/clicker questions, and homework. Practice midterm was helpful too because he goes over it in class. Overall unless you don't have previous gen chem experience it's pretty manageable and fair.

Had Ming Lee Tang Spring 2020. Cannot lecture to save her life and her train of thought is so hard to follow. Exams are hard and can not be compared to her quizzes and homework assignments. She curved it so that the top 30% got an A, middle 60% got Bs/Cs, and the bottom 10% failed.

Take MingLee Tang! She is really considerate of her students during difficult times (COVID-19, fight against police brutality). She responds to emails faster than any of my previous professors, and she uses piazzi which is really useful

First half was super easy. Second half ramped up the difficulty. It's not too bad as long as you do the homework. I had Jiang. There were no "replacing of the midterm with final score" type of redemption. But due to recent world events, he changed some grading to a "no risk" type of final.
