He gives 30% extra credit for watching his video tutorials online, and a max of 20% extra credit on quizzes, so you might not even have to take the final to get an A in the class. His lectures aren't really helpful, study off of the slides and the video tutorials for the quizzes. Quizzes are like the homework problems, just ask the TAs to go over some of the HW questions before the quiz is handed to you. If you have anyone other than Greenstein, this class is very difficult. Many of my friends who had other professors, and it was extremely hard for them. Some barely passed with a C-, but they will be prepared for CS111, which builds upon this course.
Avoid professor Bin Sun if it’s possible, his (I think) Korean accent is such a barrier that his lectures are slow as heck. We had three subsitutes and they were all far better

I had Neal Livesay. He's a nice guy but often times has trouble explaining abstract concepts like why a certain rule makes sense which is really what a lot of students struggle with since this class is not that intuitive. Honestly I felt like I didn’t really know what I was doing for most of this quarter but I just looked at his solutions for the practice problems, tried to find some sort of pattern, and did the same thing. Try to study for this class and attend lecture and make sure you have all the notes written down so you can clarify it on discussion. Still
Probably won’t make sense lol. Do well on quizzes and study for the final cuz it’s a huge chunk of the grade (50%)

Had this during coronaszn. Not sure how much that affects the difficulty of this class, but I had prof livesay and it was fairly tough. He was a great prof overall, but a lot of the shorthand notation he used nobody was fully familiar with and he acted like it was common knowledge when he'd write those hieroglyphics on the board lol. I crammed the exams bc i had other difficult classes to cater to, but I'd like to say i did fine. Just make sure you do the practice problems and try to not let this class sit on the backburner like i did. study frequently, bc a lot of this class is very new in terms of notation. its like learning another language kinda. a bunch of proofs too. however, once you get that down its pretty straightforward

Probably the easiest math class I've ever taken at UCR. The class is mostly focused on logic and proofs as opposed to raw computation but they're super easy to learn. I rarely attended lectures or discussions and got a nearly perfect score on the final.
Take this class with Neal Livesay if possible. Explains all the material very clearly and was very knowledgeable.

(Spring'21 - online) - Prof Jacob Greenstein - highly recommend you take Prof Greenstein as there are a lot of ways to earn extra credit, I didn't even give the final and ended the class with an A+ - Easy if you understand the theory but difficult otherwise. Good luck.

I took calculus back in highschool, so this class was a breeze to me. But for the people who didnt take this. this class is a bit challenging... recommend studying with a friend who is good at math carry your way to pass

Took calc in hs and got a C took Curtis's class and ended up with 102% (gives extra credit on midterms). Just do the work and you will get an A, ppl who complain about the work and don't do anything get less.
Only the quizzes are sort of easy but they are only worth 25% of the class. The midterms and final however are super hard. Doesnt help that the class was at 8 AM either.
took with curtis, if attend lecture to take notes is ez, you have to keep up
Professor Curtis is good. The class is hard, so you need to study a lot and attend class to get a good grade. The class moves through material really quickly
easy class if you took ap calc ab/bc in high school. as long as you go to lecture + take notes + review with the homework a little, you'll be fine!

Its a painnnn but Curtis does try to make it as easy as possible. Lot of self studying bc class goes too fast. Dont skip lecture. Study guides etc always match the quizzes/exams. Discussion 2x a week: one day a worksheet, one day a quiz, so cant really skip. Then 2 midterms & final exam. Tri Phan was an awesome TA, would recommend. Online hw Webassign is hell and will take up hours of a week.

Bit challenging if you haven't taken calc before. Curtis tries to make it less of a drag, he tells you exactly what will be on the midterm and final. Make sure to do all the work in discussion and go to curtis's office hours if you need help. attending lecture helps a lot even though its 8am
Curtis is assigns a lot of homework and it takes a bit of time to finish even if you are good at Calculus, but it prepares you for his tests. Work hard and you will be fine.

Just do the homework and the quizzes, and the exams aren't too difficult. Had a great TA, Matt O'Dell. Helped tremendously. Professor would tell him to give us a quiz, and he would, but everyone failed, so he allowed us to take it home and redo it. Projects aren't too difficult, just show decent effort and you'll get a 100%
Just attend discussions; lectures are basically optional.

Took this class for math minor. Midterm (mainly computational) was easy but later half of the course had alot of theory and conceptual stuff. Avoid Prof Rush, gives raw score of a B to a C, which doesn't make any sense...
Easy class, homework is online and takes about 20 minutes to do. The tests are just like the sample tests and the only mildly challenging test was the final.

I had Schmidt, Karl and he didn't really provide with anything online (iLearn). You have to go to his lecture because you won't have any notes or material (except the textbook if you find it online). His lecture is constant writing; all of the theorems and definitions. A big portion of his midterm is like true and false question and an explanation instead of solving it.

Discussion twice a week. The math itself isn't that hard but you have to justify your answer for some exam questions which requires knowing some theorems and what things actually mean rather than just memorizing a formula. This kinda messed a lot of people up. Quizzes weekly like every other math class, homework is online so you have to buy a subscription.
Easy material, hard tests

Took it with Samuelson, midterm was easy since the midterm practice was similar. Was told final would be similar to the practice final. There were 5 questions out of 13 that we never covered in the final practice or in discussion.

Do NOT take it with Samuelson. While he is a knowledgeable in the subject he's a very bland lecturer. The midterm wasn't too bad but there were at least 4-5 questions that were not previously discussed on the final. Take it with someone else and it shouldn't be difficult.

Ziv Rav is a smart guy if you understand his lectures. Teaches the class conceptually (keep in mind), but his midterm/ final are easy AS LONG AS YOU GO TO CLASS. You don't have to pay attention; the textbook is already good enough to teach you, but he does tell you what kinds of questions will be on the midterm/final exam. He will provide practice midterm/final, but only 60-70% of the questions on there will be similar on the actual midterm/final; the other 40-30% is from when he tells you in lecture. Homework was on MatLab, very easy to do. Easy class, just show up to class
Class is very easy, the midterm is a carbon copy of the sample except a couple of numbers are changed. As long as you do the homework and go to discussion you should be fine.
Very chill overall
[COVID-19 ERA] MATH031 wasn't too bad, tests not proctored only, use internet -> easy A. Final was made optional due to #BLM protests.

I had professor Yunied. He was alright in my opinion. I usually just go to the TA for more help since I thought she was more clear in teaching the material. Exams were usually only about 3-5 questions. So many theorems to know. But it's not that bad if you truly understand the proofs. Ended up with an A in the class just by completing all the homework and getting an A on the one midterm.
Easy class, material learned in this is not very hard

Take Professor Samuelson's class if you can. I had him fall 2020 and he was very understanding of the whole online schooling situation as our grade was only based on matlab and written homework. Highly recommend

I took this class with Xin Yang and I gotta say, this class was too easy. It's hard to fail this class unless you consciously avoid doing the work. He makes the practice quizzes, midterm, and final identical to the real ones. Because of this, there was no need to attend lecture or discussions, which aren't mandatory.

Took the class with prof Xin yang and he was amazing!! He thoroughly taught the subject, and always made sure we understood. He always encourages students to email him questions or attend office hours and is very kind. His sample midterm and final is almost identical to the real midterm and final. Take his class, it’s an easy A!!

I had this with Patricio Candela. This class is not the standard math class where you calculate stuff. It is more focused on theorems and T/F questions. If you want an A in this class, be prepared to study and memorize all the theorems. The calculation part is the easy part so don't focus too much on those. Be prepared to pay $60 for mymathlab.
Easy math class. Don't underestimate final
Literally everyone else I have talked to said this class was super easy, it was one of the hardest maths I have taken. Avoid Daniel Guan at ALL COSTS.
The class as a whole is fairly simple. The midterm average was a 90% for all three sections. Nonetheless, the final was a bit more difficult compared to the midterm, so do not underestimate it.

Extremely easy class until the last chapter. Written homework and quizzes are worded odd and semi-ambiguous on what they ask. Take Zhixian Zhu as she has a clear passion for teaching and will go over step-by-step on difficult problems.
Relatively easy and straightforward math class as long as you know your calculus fundamentals i.e. techniques of integration and derivatives.
Had Diaz. Exams were generally like his quizzes and HW, nothing like his lectures (bc he made-up the problems as he lectured).Very simple. Mainly integration and derivatives.

This class was pretty hard for me, mostly because I couldn't wrap my head around the processes behind it. Read the book, Schaum's Outlines of Differentials is well written and helps out a lot if your professor sucks.
Yunied sucks tbh. Makes everything harder than it needs to be because it “stimulates” his brain

If you don't get an A, you either made some really dumb mistakes along the way or you need to reevaluate how you tackle college courses. As a UC transfer, this course was tied with the easiest course I have ever taken.

Super easy class with Zhixian Zhu! Recommend this professor. Material was a bit intimidating at first, but gets easy once you get the hang of the class. The averages for the final and midterm were a high B.

Take Qixuan Wang. Written HW is graded by completion, midterm and final were only 4 problems and she tells you what will be on them. There is webwork most weeks but they only have a handful of problems (and the worst 2 are dropped). Posts slides but doesn't include solution to examples, which doesn't really matter because the material itself is very easy. You would have to actually try if you wanted to fail.

I had Savanna Gee, and she has been my favorite professor at UCR so far (after 4 quarters). She makes the content very easy to understand. Just take the lessons one day at a time, do some practice, and you'll get 100% on the final. If you want to get ahead, look over Linear, Bernoulli, Exact, & Homogeneous differential equations. If you haven't taken Linear Algebra, you gotta understand the Wronskian.

I took the class with Scott Atkinson, and I thought that the class was relatively difficult considering the fact that I did not take calculus for 2 years. It was difficult to get concepts at first. I had to do several problems from the book in addition to doing the online homework. Do not underestimate the midterm and final.

Had PoNing. Make sure to study for inexact differential equations, cauchy euler differential equations, mixing word problems, and newton's law of cooling as these are the hardest concepts in the class. Overall, class wasn't too difficult.

Optimization: Taken with Ali Pakzad.  Midterm was very easy.  Did not go to class once after the midterm and still ended up with an A-.  Just do the practice problems on the notes and HW and you should be fine.

Professor Tucker taught the class pretty well. Has a standard grading system, so no curves but that already tells you that the class is easy. Provides practice midterm and final prior to the test which are identical. Discussion worksheets = easy true and false. Homeworks are tedious, but they help with your learning.
(covid era) Took it with Henry Tucker. I hated this class, didn't understand anything. Somehow got an A+

Kevin Costello. Good guy. The homework is due usually once per week, on Wednesdays. Discussion was held on Tuesday, the day before the hw was due, which was a big help due to the TA going over homework problems. The content itself wasn't too bad. Starts with graphs, and goes into probability. The first half of the course is easy enough, mainly graph theory and the like. The second part was slightly more difficult imo, due to the types of problems introduced. There were two midterms and one final exam. When i took the course, we were allowed one sided "cheat sheet" for both midterms. The final allowed a double sided sheet. All in all difficulty wise, a pretty average upper division math course. Not terribly difficult, but still can be challenging. Grade received: B

This class goes over graphs and counting things (inclusion-exclusion, Catalan numbers, generating functions, etc.). There was a homework assignment every week. Many problems consisted of proving things, but they were quite simple. There was a midterm and a final, both of which were doable. Go to office hours if you need help.

I had Henry Tucker as my professor. He made midterm and final available all day so that was a huge plus, worth 20% each. Too many problems on the homework and I couldn't do a lot of them on my own without trying to find the answers online or getting help from the TA as the lecture notes weren't very helpful. Also has a group project worth 20% where we recorded our own presentation on a math concept we learned in class. Then discussion worksheets were 20% which were a lot easier than homework. Honestly surprised I ended with a B so I guess I'm happy for that.

Taken with Professor Xu. It's the first proof-based class I and many other students have taken. It's very abstract and conceptual, just very different from lower division maths. CS011/MATH011 is a good course to prepare or reinforce the type of concepts for 131.

Zhu is a great professor, it's hard to teach Math131 in general. Curved the class very generously, as long as you do well on your homeworks (i.e. All A's on each homework and a B on the midterm), you are on track for an A in the class.

Had the class with Javier Gonzalez, excellent instructor. The material itself is not hard but it is a proof based class so sometimes it can be tricky to fully justify and understand certain concepts. Lectures and discussions were very useful and I would highly recommend office hours, they are very helpful for the homework. We had 6 homework assignments, 6 quizzes (lowest quiz dropped), 2 midterms and a final. Midterms were very fair and as long as you do understand the hw you should at least get 80%, only a small portion of it was tricky. The exam was cumulative so it was a little harder, but still extremely fair. I did well on the hw and quizzes and averaged about 80% for the exams which gave me an 85% for the class which was an A-.

I took Math132 with Professor Gindi. I've had him for 3 classes so far and he is a great professor but he and his TA's have graded super strict for every class I've had him with. 132 is 2nd level linear algebra and the material is fairly abstract and somewhat dense. Spend a lot of time studying and truly understanding the concepts. The midterm and final did not have a practice test but were mostly based on in class examples and homework problems (Gindi has done this for all of his classes)
If you don't have a good grasp of Linear Algebra it'll be really tough.
Taken with Xiao Xinli.  Barely passed, was completely lost the whole quarter but the curve was very generous.  Midterm and Final averages were below 50%.

I got an A+ in 131 and still struggled with this class. Took with professor Gan online and let me tell you, this class was HARD. I don't know where he was getting his problems from but there were zero similar examples to be found anywhere. His homework and exams were open everything (even internet) as long as you did not discuss with others on exams. His office hours were helpful too but it was still hard as hell. I studied the book religiously. I've had him before and he was great but this class was on a whole different level.

I had Professor Lihan, the class was heavy on proofs, the homework was more difficult than the exams. There was a presentation on topology topics (which was on material beyond the scope of this class). Overall average difficulty for upper division math course

Fall20 with Schultz. As with any class taught by Schultz, I didn't pay attention to lectures, never really read through his material, still got an A. You can get through the first half knowing hs geometry, the second half introduced a few new things but nothing terrible. 3 quizzes, 2 exams, the Schultz usual.

description: INTRODUCTION TO THE THEORY OF NUMBERS

comments.comment: Math136 is number theory and I took is with professor Livesay. Even though it was his first time teaching number theory, he did an excellent job and I found myself truly enjoying the class. Homework assignments are lengthy but not too difficult and graded fairly. Make sure you know both your proofs and calculations and you should end up doing very well on the midterm and final.

Math144 is set theory. I took it with Brian Benson who is very enthusiastic and passionate about the class. The material itself starts off not too bad but in my experience quickly became very abstract and difficult to understand. Homework, midterm, and final were all graded pretty strictly but the curve is generous. All around, a decently hard class

This is basically supposed to be an intro to proofs class. Took it with Schultz. He doesn't use ilearn but instead uploads files to a directory which you have to check regularly since you aren't notified when he adds something new. Lectures were hard to sit through. Honestly I relied on my TA to get me through this class, he did a very good job of explaining the material. Schultz would post a lot of practice problems which I would then go ask the TA how to do them. We were graded on a midterm, 3 quizzes, and a final. Big curves, 64-84 was a B on his midterm lol. I think Math/cs011 would be good prep for this class.

I think this class was difficult just because it's Topology. It's a confusing course. I took 145A with Schultz, and while he's a bright man, his teaching style doesn't help me learn Topology. So, I took 145B with Atkinson. He's a pretty organized and good professor, and he had a good TA too so that helped me SOMEWHAT understand things. However, if you can avoid Topology in general, I would.

Math146C is Partial Differential Equations, this course unlike parts A and B can be quite challenging. Understanding the method for separation of variables and the Sturm-Liouville problem are essentials. It also wouldn't hurt to know some Fourier analysis as some PDE's can only be solved in such a manner. All in all the class will test your abilities and the test's won't be a walk in the park like parts A and B.

description: INTRODUCTION TO CHAOTIC AND COMPLEX DYNAMICAL SYSTEMS

comments.comment: I had this class with Michel Lapidus. Our grade was based on attendance and participation (15%, half-half), homework (40%), and a project (45%). Luckily, there were no quizzes or tests; I had no idea what was being taught. There were 2 homeworks. They were made up of problems from the book and problems he gave during lecture and we weren't required to do all of them. We had the option of doing the project in a group or individually (I was in a group). The professor barely gave us any idea what to do on it. He said a presentation is usually mandatory but because all this took place during the pandemic, the presentation was extra credit. Be sure to take notes during lecture because he doesn't post his online. Also, I went to every lecture and discussion but apparently that wasn't enough to get full points for attendance and participation. My final grade was a B. I decided to take this class because I wanted to learn something new, but I was left disappointed. I would not recommend taking this class with this professor.

This class was really easy when you take it with Schultz. ALTHOUGH, I took it as a fully online course (hello COVID-19 pandemic). He literally gives you everything you need to do well! Also, the content was pretty interesting. I think it could be difficult as an in-person course, but not really. It kind of helps to take MATH136, because some of the concepts are brought up again in MATH153. Overall, I liked this class.

Math165B is the second portion to complex variables. Unlike in part A, 165B offers a bit more intricacy when it comes to the proofs, more often then not they are non-trivial integrals over contours which require some sneaky substitutions and a decent ability to solve integrals. Much like 165A, the HW is still tedious and full of repetitive calculations and some tricky proof questions. Ideally one should have a decent grasp of 165A to do well for 165B.

ACTUALLY DO THE HOMEWORK. If you truly understand the concepts of the homework you'll breeze through the midterms. If you have Princevac be warned the final will be the factor that determines whether you pass the weeder course or not.

You cover the basics of the whole ME curriculum in this one class. Two midterms, one final. You need to do good on at least one midterm because the final ends up killing everyones grade. There is a class curve at the end, but you need to make sure you make the original cutoff for a passing grade. I had stahovich so the cutoff was a 62% for a C. The majority of the class does fail however. 

Homework will take a good 6-8 hours to complete, quizzes are really bad, and you're expected to spend the majority of your time on this class.

Stahovich was a good professor.
This was probably the hardest class I have taken so far (entering 2nd year), so STUDY UP AND DONT SLACK. I barely made it through with a C, but most of my friends did not

Hands down the most difficult weedout course in engineering: they told us on day 1 that only a third of us were expected to get above a C (there is no curve for Princevac), 60% of my class failed. ME2 is designed to make you think like an engineer, not teach you material, which trips up a LOT of people... questions are based on “figure out how to solve the problem” instead of “plug numbers into an equation”. No equation sheets, majority symbolic (mass m1, etc) and only simple calculators, all about your ability to solve problems. If you’re into that, ME2 will be your favorite underclassman course; if not, join the 60%.
Material isn't particularly hard, there is just a lot of info that is covered and the test problems tend to be fairly complex. Your set up is more important than the actual calculations.

You are going to be surprised when you take this class in your first or second year because it take a lot more effort to get good grades than other lower div classes. It probably exists just to scare off students and make them feel ME is not right for them. I sure wish someone told me this class would be so disgusting beforehand because I was definitely not ready for it.

I took this class with Princevac. Class is difficult because of content and heavy emphasis on exam scores, only about 7 A's my year out of a class of 80+. Huge help if you take PHYS040B concurrently (a lot of the topics align such as buoyant forces, and efficiency).

What helped me the most to get an A is having access to 100% correct answers from Chegg or solution keys from previous years. Having accurate solutions helped in two ways: one, saved my homework grade and, two, gave me the right answers to study from when it came to the exam time. Midterm 1, 4/5 problems were seen previously in either homework or quizzes. Midterm 2, 3/5 problems were seen already. Go to office hours to check if your solutions are 100% correct, so you don't miss any points on the exam. Outside of his lectures, you should start applying the principles in the real world and think, "what are the forces acting on this system?" or "Why does this work/built this way?". Ultimately this class should start to make you think like an engineer. Keep in mind this class is supposed to be somewhat enjoyable, and stay humble because it only gets harder from here.

I took the class with Akula Venkatram for winter 2021. EXTREMELY ROUGH time, he knows his stuff, but horrible at teaching. Would act like a child with poor test scores, and doesn't seem to care about his students. But gave nice curve at the end. The homework did not reflect the quizzes and tests much, hes a very conceptual based professor.

CAD Assignments were ridiculously easy at first but slowly progressed in difficulty. You also take the CSWA Exam at the end of the quarter and only 40% of my class passed the exam (which is apparently normal according to the professor).
Honestly, if you just read the textbook and do well on the CAD Assignments (CAD is 40% of your grade), you'll be fine.

Took with Sawyer. The class itself was relatively easy. You should be fine as long as you do the CAD assignments and the homework. When he does examples in SolidWorks in class, it'll be hard to keep up with him at first, but it should become easier over time. The questions on the Midterm and Final were almost identical and looked like it turned the textbook readings into questions themselves. Okay class overall.

CADS is 40% of your grade, always do them and make sure there's annotation. TA grades super harsh, if you make one small mistake, you get 1/3 to even more than half the credits off your assignments/midterm/CAD. I had to take it as a first year student, with 0 experiences in Engineering because of block, I had so much trouble and everything feels like there is suppose to be a prerequisite class.

Im a CE major, took the class for the "other" engineering requirement
if you dont want to go into ME or you didnt do too well in physics then this class will be HARD otherwise you should be fine

I'm an MSE and this class was a struggle. I pushed all of my other classes to the side for this class. Tons of time put in outside of class to understand the concepts that Stahovich zooms through in lecture. If you love ME, physics, and have a good understanding of MATH010A ahead of time, you'll be fine.

Prof. Eskandari taught the class very well. HW were easy, quizzes were her lecture notes. 2 Midterms; midterms represented of homework problems and lecture example problems. Final were problems from practice final. Every time she says hint hint or wink wink, that's an indication you'll see that problem either on a quiz, midterm, or final. Take her hints seriously if you want an A. Also go to her office hours for extra credit. Great professor
No midterm only, quizzes and final. Hw 20% quiz 30% and final 50%. Professor Xu is funny and all, but he doesnt really know how to teach

description: KINEMATIC AND DYNAMIC ANALYSIS OF MECHANISMS
ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF ENERGY PRODUCTION AND CONVERSION

comments.comment: The class was quite easy, but that gave me a false sense of security so I didn't perform as I expected in the end. The class material is diverse, but relatively simple. Take the labs seriously, as the lab memos (the assignments) make up most of the class grade. There's extensive use of MATLAB when examining the lab results. Overall, don't slack and procrastinate,  just put in some effort and it's an easy A.

The class is pretty easy and is almost a guaranteed A. The final was a bit harder than the midterm so I had a false sense of security that almost made me lose my A. Really focus on the labs as those make 50% of your grade and can make or break your grade at the end.

description: NANOSCALE HEAT TRANSFER AND ENERGY CONVERSION
TRANSPORT PROCESSES IN THE ATMOSPHERIC BOUNDARY LAYER
FINITE ELEMENT METHODS IN SOLID MECHANICS
OPTICS AND LASERS IN ENGINEERING AND APPLIED SCIENCE

comments.comment: Any mcs class with Anderson is an easy A

Half of the course content is a rehashing of MCS001 and the rest of the course content is media theories. Professor Su is flexible and understanding. Your grade is based on the midterm (multiple choice) and final (2 essay questions). The only downside of this course lectures arent reuploaded, but fairly simple class.

Took with Anderson during Covid Winter 2021 and it was pretty easy. All lectures were prerecorded and discussions aren't mandatory. The lectures are kind of boring and long but would have probably been better in person. No final exam, but there's a final project which is making a blog. Do all of the lecture pps and only need to do 4 discussion pps for full pp credit. Easy A

description: CULTURAL STUDIES: HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY PERSPECTIVES

comments.comment: attend review sessions before the midterm and final and you should be okay for the exams.

Midterms are specific about the readings and lecture notes. Go to lecture, she (setsu) tells you what is going to be on the midterm. She seems nice but is kinda unapproachable because she judges you so hard. Rachel (TA) was the best!! she replied fast on emails, graded things on time, and created summaries for the readings (i read those summaries for midterms instead of doing the readings)

description: DRUG MARKETS AS CONFORMITY AND RESISTANCE
MAJOR FIGURES IN FILM AND MEDIA
LIVE-STREAMING AND GAMING ENTHNOGRAPHY: ONLINE RESEARCH METHODS
ASIAN AMERICAN WOMEN: WRITING THE SELF IN LITERATURE AND FILM
DISNEY: PRODUCING RACE, GENDER AND SEXUALITY
ALTERNATIVE MEDIA PRODUCTION AND SOCIAL MOVEMENTS
AFROFUTURISM & THE VISUAL CULTURES OF HORROR
BERLIN METROPOLIS IN LITERATURE, FILM, MUSIC, AND ART

comments.comment: Hsiao has pretty simple exams.  Watch out for his free response questions cuz they take longer than you might think.  Pretty fair for 50 mins and no cumulative final.  Uses TopHat for extra credit and assigned a powerpoint group presentation in discussion.  Very straightforward class overall.

Interesting class but Wenbo Ma had really hard exams & her TA was a super. She had the audacity to get mad at us when the average was mid 50s.. don't you know the common denominator between all of us is having YOU as a professor?

Lab reports are easy but long and tedious, so don't make the same mistake I did and start late. Make sure you format them correctly. You can expect to pull an all-nighter if you start the night before. Coffey grades somewhat harshly on the scientific paper for some strange reason, so expect points off even if you show it to him and he gives the ok. The midterms are easy if you pay attention in class (no final). Go for the extra credit points!

Rao gave weird test questions and stuff that wasn't really mentioned in class/taught on the slides. Luckily, the last half of the class was taught by Dr. Morrison, who was much more straightforward in what she expected of us. The final was legitimately difficult. Rao doesn't give "-" final overall grades, so you could go from an A to a B+, B directly to a C+, etc. Definitely wouldn't recommend unless you want your ass kicked by a massive GPA dropper like this. Also, Rao likes to eat away at your grade with hard pop quizzes in lecture. Memorization is heavily tested in this course.

Class based mostly on lab work--3 days a week. Prof and TA kinda unorganized but overall grading was extremely fair. There is a scientific paper on your lab work and a final presentation on personal research. These are due during week 10 so get ready for a major time crunch. Study slides for all tests and exams.

Dr. Borneman is super nice and grades very fairly. This class tests common sense and knowledge (mostly) but the tests will get harder over time. There is memorization of class material tested on the 2nd midterm and final. There are also small assignments due throughout the quarter, so don't forget to turn them in! Everything you will need to know will be in his class slides! Very interesting and informative class.

description: SEMINAR IN MOLECULAR BIOLOGY AND GENOMICS OF DISEASE VECTORS
EARLY MODERN EMPIRES IN THE MIDDLE EAST: THE OTTOMANS AND THE SAFAVIDS

comments.comment: Francis Moore is a super nice violinists. I have her as my violin instructor. Just do the work and put some effort and you'll get an A
Super Easy A. I took it with Frances Moore and it filled my humanities breadths. Attendance is mandatory tho.

Dr. Walter Clark is good. He doesn't care if you don't show up, though you REALLY should because he doesn't upload lecture notes, which tests are 100% based on, and you can't really get the information anywhere else. Not much material to memorize. Just go to lecture and copy what he writes down + you'll be completely fine
I took this class fully online with Professor Moore. It was pretty easy, although it's hard to learn music online. Concepts are easy and not too much work.
Literally, go to class. BS the assignments. Go to class, and he will give you answers to the final.

description: HISTORY OF WESTERN MUSIC: TWENTIETH CENTURY

comments.comment: Concert Band/Wind Ensemble, literally only graded on attendance. Dr. Andress is pretty chill.

description: SEMINAR IN SPECIAL TOPICS IN MUSICOLOGY
ELECTROACOUSTIC MUSIC:  HISTORY, THEORY, AND AESTHETICS
DIRECTED STUDIES IN THE TEACHING OF MUSIC
LOWER DIVISION SEMINAR IN THE NATURAL AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES

comments.comment: (Fall 2020 Online) This class is for the PERSIST Research program. I had Dr. Nugent and it was honestly a pleasure. She is a sweet soul that is absolutely intelligent and intimidating because of it haha. Nonetheless, she allowed a welcoming environment that had room for errors and asking questions. I learned a lot from her in this course even though at times the course seemed to be a little unorganized.

description: READING AND ANALYSIS OF SCIENTIFIC ARTICLES

comments.comment: Aquaponics. Fun.
You don't even have to read for this class just memorize the slides and listen to the lectures. Took it with Andreja Novakovic

Really easy class. The readings are basically useless because all the material you need for tests comes from the slides. Professor Novakovic isn't challenging anyone that much in this class since many people just take it to fill a breadth requirement. Just listen to what she says during lectures
Novachovic: If you attend the lectures and pay attention, you can succed. Paying attention and reading the passage ensures an easy B+ or A
Don't take it with Keller. He teaches the subject in a strange way and is difficult to listen to.
Professor Wood is a great professor. No mid term, no final, just 3 papers throughout the quarter.

Took with Dr. Joshua Wood. Pretty straightforward class. 3 essays, and each essay added an extra prompt on top of the previous one. (Ex. If essay one asked you to explain an argument, the second essay asked you to do the same, and give a counterargument.) Essays were graded by the TA, No Midterm or Final Exam

Had Joshua Wood. This class really shouldn't have been that hard, but I had a picky TA who didn't use the professor's grading scale for the essays. No midterm, no final- just papers. Go to your TA's office hours to find out what exactly they are looking for in the essays. Barely have to show up to lecture

Took with John Fischer, extremely easy, your grade really depends on your TA, was able to get extra credit points, read the lecture slides and you're fine, you don't need to do the readings, no paper just 2 midterms and a final; show up to discussions
The class itself was fairly easy. You don't even need to read. The people who determine your "fate" are your T.A'S. Everything is graded by your T.A.

Taken with Luca Ferrero. He is a good professor, but he over-explains a bunch of concepts for most who are taking this class as a breadth course. The quizzes are TOUGH. You have 3 hours and it is technically open note, but its nearly impossible ton find the answer in a straightforward manner. Very weird grading scale - TA's do literally determine your grade and fate so be nice to them.

Took it with professor Swanson. Just 3 papers, rarely attended lecture all slides are online but ask the TAs for help if you want a good grade on your paper. It seems straightforward but they have high expectations for them
Took it with Dr. Wood & very helpful if you go to lectures, the exams and finals weren't too bad as long as you went to lecture
took it with Swanson, just 3 paper, nothing hard

I took it with Wood. I would say, if you can connect with what's being said at lecture with the readings, this is an okay class. Somewhat lots of reading (ranging from like a short article to a chpt) for each class but overall, I think it was actually okay. The lectures and readings are kinda interesting and I didn't feel drowsy/kept up with the lectures. Would recommend if you're okay with reading/looking at things from someone else's POV

I had Swanson as prof and Andrew as TA. The material itself wasn't that bad, however the lectures (asynchronous on mondays and synchronous on wednesdays) were really long and full of information. Taking notes is important because a lot of the quiz/test material was from the lecture. For the papers, ask your TA what they're looking for because they help grade. Our midterm was 25 multiple choice and 5 essay (~ a paragraph answer) questions and was curved because not a lot of people finished and our final was an essay. we also had weekly quizzes but you could work with other people on them

description: ETHICS AND THE MEANING OF LIFE

comments.comment: This class definitely requires some effort but honestly it was pretty interesting and I really liked the prof (Snelson).

Professor (Coleen) was very poor at using time effectively in class. Often rambled/discussed some meaningless corner case for our content. Course material itself isnt too hard however. Book is also somewhat verbose and reading it can be a challenge. Quizzes are 90% of your grade (10% each, 9 total, during discussion). I HIGHLY suggest getting Akshay Ganesh for TA. He releases his personal notes the day before his discussion and they are extremely helpful. There are in class quizzes which are worth around 5% of your grade. The class is curved to a B-. As long as you do well on the weekly quizzes in your discussion, you'll do fine.

Professor Londen was really nice. The only way to prepare for the quizzes and to get an A honestly is to meet up with him during office hours and ask him to give some more examples of the sorts of questions he wants us to answer. Show up to lecture!

Prof. Londen teaches this class and is super nice and willing to help, you just have to communicate. This class was very difficult because you are learning a new skill. The class is curved though so I believe a 50% was actually a C. If you want to pass the class with an A which is 100% possible, start off strong and go to office hours starting week 2 before your first exam. There is a test every week so go to office hours every week because everything is built ontop of everything so if you dont understand something from a previous week it will harm you the entire quarter. The TAs and prof all grade each individual exam together so they try to give you as many points as possible. Final exam is optional.
Since I was in honors, I had the professor as my TA in discussion. Very helpful and easy class. Got an A. It was more of an online class
very easy to learn everything, the end of the quarter is where it gets a bit hard, but nothing scary.

The professor Nagashima himself is a nice guy who is trying his best to teach. The class however I found a bit difficult. In the beginning the class was very easy to follow and was going at a steady pace Then out of nowhere towards the last couple of weeks we get thrown these difficult concepts which had little relation to what we learned in the beginning. Must have time to study outside of class or you will bomb the second midterm and final. I managed an A on both midterms but I invested quite a bit of time in study groups etc. It’s passable but as a breadth class it was a bit stressful.

The class can get confusing if you have Michael Nelson but as long as you go to every lecture and disscusion and pay attention then you should do fine. 4-10 problems for homework a week but some hw sets may take a few hours. The concepts can be a little hard to grasp but the classwork is fairly low. Never studies for both midterms and I got an 88% on both.

Took it with Michael Nelson. This guy is so confusing in his lectures, and he wrote the book, which is worded just as he talks. Hard class tbh. Got an A minus because the final was hard as hell, even after getting a 94 and 100 on my two midterms, and over 100% on my homework.

this class is definitely hit or miss; like either you'll find it super easy and get an A+ or you won't understand jackshit. if you're familiar with cs this class won't be too bad bc it's basically all boolean like true/false. but prof nelson is definitely not a good teacher and is super confusing. if you have mcdonald as your ta you'll be fine tho.

I had Professor Erich Reck, the materials might be difficult depending on how much you can comprehend logic, but the class is relative easy to pass. You get 3 tries for homework, extra credit problems on (most) quizzes and midterms. It is an easy A if you do homework, attend discussion, and watch lecture

I took this class with Andrew Law and he mentions this early on in the course but this course is easy in the beginning but it gets extremely difficult towards the end. We used an online website (Carnap) to do basically everything on but it was free so you don't have to pay anything. Just make sure you pay close attention especially after the first midterm since that's when stuff really picks up and gets confusing. I recommend attending every lecture because if you miss one you can get really far behind. There's also weekly homework, 2 midterms and the final.

In my experience, CS/CE/EE majors easily carry this class while other majors may struggle a bit. The first half is just truth tables and logic functions, which are both super easy. The second half is all proofs, which is where some of the class started to struggle. About half the class ended with As and the other half got Cs/Ds. This is basically a math class disguised as a philosophy class so just keep that in mind.

Took it with Prof Andrew Law online, he's an amazing lecturer and professor. He really cares about his students and is always available for help and questions. He would host review sessions before the midterms and the final. The first half of the class was a breeze but the second half (derivations) was a lot harder. The class is like PHIL007 in that there's no philosophical readings, rather learning a skill set and applying it to arguments and checking if arguments are valid or not. 2 midterms, 1 final, weekly homework sets due sunday night, discussion, book readings were recommended and uploaded on ilearn.

If you're taking it with Jeremy Pober, expect a pretty easy class. He's a great professor and lectures very clearly so that the material (which can be sometimes challenging) is broken down into simple concepts. You're going to write two papers, with the first paper being 10% of your grade and the second paper being 15%, but both are only 1.5 pages long. The midterm was easy for me and I anticipate the final on being equally simple. On his exams, he dedicates 5 questions for you to explain your previous answers and, if he thinks they're acceptable explanations, you will be able to earn the points back if you missed the question. Overall, pretty enjoyable experience; I would take him again.

description: PHILOSOPHICAL ISSUES OF RACE AND GENDER
PROSEMINAR FOR FIRST-YEAR GRADUATE STUDENTS: METAPHYSICS AND EPISTEMOLOGY
THIRD AND FOURTH YEAR RESEARCH SEMINAR

comments.comment: Take Gabor. He's absolutely amazing
Hai Bo Yu doesn't help with MasteringPhysics and the textbook isn't good.

Professor Hai Bo Yu was a nice guy, but his accent made it hard to understand sometimes, and he mostly just read off of premade lecture slides straight from the textbook. I learned everything from doing the homework and from watching videos online, not from him.
Exams are unpredictable. Avoid Joshua Lui. Other professors are much better.
Joshua Lui is okay, but exams were a bit hard. Allows you a formula sheet.
Easy homework and clickers. Hard tests

Had Yongtao Cui. Was concerned since he has 0 ratings online so I didn't know what to expect. However, he's a decent professor. Exams are quite hard, midterms averages about 40-50%, same as final. Important to not fall back in this class as the material is quite hard to understand without going to class. I scored 20-25% above exam averages and that got me an A.

Difficult because many students are balancing this class with CHEM 008A. Definitely recommend you to read up on each chapter during the weekend before the lecture. It helps you understand the material early on. I also recommend that you do the practice problems in the textbook for additional practice outside of HW. If you have Peng Wei, I recommend to go to office hours and ask him for help especially if you're falling behind.

Took it with YongTao Cui. A very caring professor but a hard class. Averages for exams were about 40% but there was a fat curve at the end. Definitely do practice questions and make sure you understand the concepts.

I took this class with Beyermann in the summer of 2020. Would not recommend. His tests are difficult. Furthermore, the hw he assigns aren't similar to what the tests looks like. Granted that this class was in 5 weeks so take this with a grain of salt.

Took the class with Beyermann over the summer, would not recommend with him because it was my first time taking physics so I was really lost, midterms were really hard 30-60% averages, final was doable. Try finding someone else first

"Never took PHYS, but taking it with Professor John Ellison was the best choice ever! He is very patient in answering questions during lecture, reexplains concepts that are hard/what he thinks most students struggle with, and is very very understanding of the pandemic conditions! His midterm is very similar to his practice exams and homework is difficult so if you struggle with that don't worry to much just make sure to understand the practice exams and concepts. Final is NOT cumulative so that helps too. Does online clickers for credit so class is kinda mandatory and I never read his reading notes before lecture, but doing that would've helped me .
PHYS 2A is known as a weeder class, but I learned a lot and walked out with a B+ because of Prof Ellison so definitely take it with him!"

Took it with Beyermann online during Spring 2021. His grading system is very fair; I just suck at physics. Study a lot and do extremely well on the first midterm, because the material gets really difficult after that. Also try to get as many points as possible on the poll questions because the amount to as much as a midterm. We had 2 midterms and a cumulative final. Try to stay on top of the material as much as possible, because it is really easy to fall behind.

Joshua Lui was very clear, but his exams are hard. It's almost unfair. His lectures glosses over the topic for the day. His homework was okay. It didn't help. His curves are okay, but theres definitely professors who has better. I would not recommend.
Avoid Anderson. Google "UCSD 1C final exam" and there's over 100 practice problems from the equivalent course at UCSD
Simple class, simple work, and extremely high grade boosts in Barton's class.

(Took online in Winter 2021 with John Barton) This was the easiest of the Physics 2 series for me. Content-wise, it has some topics from gen chem, which makes it familiar and a bit easier to understand. His exams were all multiple choice and open note. Quite a few problems were similar to practice exams and it was not difficult to do well in the class as long as you know how to do practice exam questions and the lecture examples. A lot of it is just knowing how to use the formulas/equations, so sometimes just knowing how to do math can help you solve the problems! Since the exams are on the easier side, he doesn't curve much so 90 = A, 75 = B, and 60 = C, but if averages are low, he may change the cutoffs slightly. The professor you take for physics in general will determine how well you do since some professors give more difficult exams, but will curve or adjust cutoffs accordingly.

Anderson; I would say this class is the easiest within the series. Though, it doesn't mean that it's a walk in the park. Anderson was one of the laziest professors. He sent us into breakout rooms so we can discuss with each other. He goes into the breakout room one time and ask if everything is okay. He leaves before we can respond. The only perk is that his study guide/discussion questions is almost exactly like the exams. He changes the number, but it's not difficult to grasp.

description: COLOR AND SOUND: DIMENSIONS IN COMMUNICATION

comments.comment: This class is a good mix of memorization and conceptual math. It can be difficult for some people who struggle with memorization or math. However, if you put in a lot of effort, you'll definitely finish with at least a B. Attend lectures, practice on MasteringPhysics and do the practice midterms/finals. There is a major curve at the end, so don't stress too much. The midterm and final averages were around a 60 percent.

description: EXPLORING THE UNIVERSE: AN ADVENTURE IN ASTRONOMY

comments.comment: Took with Frederick Hamann, it was online because the campus shutdown. Midterm 30%, Final 40%, Quizzes 30%. We took the quizzes each week at the discussion session, it's only 2 questions. He gave us study guides for the midterm and final and also released all the possible quiz questions for the current week every week, that's how I managed to get an A in the class. No math to do or formulas to memorize in this class, you just need to remember vocab and concepts. Go to lecture and take notes.
Good grades if you do the labs properly.  Easy final.

They may have changed it, but I took Fall 2018 and the labs were literally the WORST experience I've had at UCR. However, the final was really easy and there was a curve so it isn't hard to get an A, just an annoying class to take.

I think it is imperative to read the lab before you come to class so you have somewhat of an idea to complete the lab. It will help save you a lot of points and time. It also helps to ask the TA for certain sections in the lab. In addition, final assessment was done online (as a timed iLearn exam). Honestly, if you are well prepared for the lecture and know how to do the labs, you should be able to ace the final exam. P.S. You are allowed to use your lab notebook during quizzes and the final assessment, so write down those formulas and concepts if you need it (as a cheat sheet). :)

Took it online during Spring 2021. The lab notebooks were extremely difficult because they are very concept-based and require you to derive formulas you learn in lecture. To study for the final, read through your lab notebooks and the corrections TAs make so you know what you did wrong.
Write everything in your lab notebook and the final is a piece of cake.  Labs weren't too difficult either.
Tsai is a terrrible professor but huge curves
homework was difficult. Practice exam was almost exactly the same as real exams. Hardest of the 40 series imo

I had Boerge as my professor and would honestly recommend him to anyone. He posts his lectures online and is very passionate about Physics + wants everyone to succeed. Make sure to go to his office hours in order to get any clarifications sorted out. If you also have Boerge, he basically covers 99% of the material from the textbook so you do not really have to read (although he will quiz you some concepts from the textbook during clickers).
In terms of the class, if you suffered through 40A, you will definitely suffer through 40B. The midterm was fairly simple, as it only covered about three chapters, but the final will definitely kill everyone's grade (however, it is not cumulative).
Discussions are mandatory and there was a quiz every class -- something not mentioned in the syllabus. According to my TA, 50% of one's discussion grade is based off attendance and the other 50% is based off the quiz grades.
Clickers were not based off participation -- something that is different from 40A. Make sure you attend every class as those points will matter.

The individual concepts and homework aren't too bad, the main difficultly in the class comes from the fact that all 3 professors write 1/3rd of the final and how Mills combines different concepts from the entire course into one question. For example this quarter(winter 2018) he somehow combined pistons, ideal gases, heat of vaporization, and thermodynamics into a single fucking question. Even if you understand the physics behind all these concepts perfectly, his questions feel like a puzzle. As far as I can tell, the other two professors make extremely "easy" straightforward questions and the curve is usually pretty nice. 

In the past, you would want to avoid Mills because he makes the hardest questions and he doesn't teach that well but now that all the professors are making the final, it might actually be beneficial to have him as a professor because you could get used to his madness before the final.
The class is pretty reasonable and doable and the midterm isn't that bad. The final was nothing like any of the practice or homework. It was extremely difficult and ridiculous

Content is relatively straight forward and homework reflects what is taught in class. Quizzes are ripped straight from the homework, so do the HW before discussion. Midterm and final are difficult, but practice exams should prepare you for them. Fat curve at the end of the class.

Most people will have a harder time with this than 40A, so it's important to read the book and make sure you're keeping up with the material. It mainly focuses on waves, but there is some heat transfer involved. I had Igor Barsukov. His tests are pretty hard but the curves are huge, I got a 45% on the midterm, which curved to a B.

Tsai is unbelievably boring. The lectures are legitimately a waste of everyones time, too bad there are clicker questions for points. The lab is shitty, but easy. Online homework is on chegg. Pretty sure I got an A despite missing most lectures. Definitely a self-study class.
Professor Long was so nice but he expects a lot of outside reading and work especially if you wanna do well on the exams. Hardest class in the phys040 series

I had Pryadko, and it's very hard to follow lecture. The textbook was a lifesaver. I would rate this class higher (I ended up rating it a 6), but Pryadko's curve makes it so a 55% is a C-. Without that curve, this class would be a 9 at minimum.
Labs were quite time consuming as the manuals weren't very well written. Not too bad of a class though, just know how to use the formulas and you should be good
Do not take with Long. He makes the tests unnecessarily hard.
About the same difficulty as Phys40A. Took it with Tanedo Winter 2021. If able, take this with Tanedo, he will make your life and physics so much easier.

Took PHYS040B with Tanedo. With Tanedo, this class was super easy. No quizzes, no tests, no midterm, no final. We have to make these weekly videos explaining how to do certain problems from the textbook every week and grade our peers on their videos. i think it's an effective learning format. Tanedo is genuinely such a nice guy and an amazing prof. Highly recommend taking 040B with him if you can. The labs are kinda painful imo, but they aren't too terrible.

try to take with Tanedo. he's the absolute best. no examinations, and he genuinely cares about how you are doing in the class and wants you to learn. grade based on you making explainer videos to show how to solve 2 physics problem given by him every week. made physics easy and entertaining, really is one of the best professors

Take this class with Phillip Tanedo if you can. It was literally a free class and the easiest A+ out of any class. About two videos a week and that's pretty much it. You'd have to try pretty hard not to get an A with Tanedo.
Much more difficult than 40B.
About the same as 40B, but no practice exams provided means I didn't do as well on the midterms/finals.

The class, itself, is really difficult and I struggled through it the entire quarter. Professor Sales, however, was a wonderful professor and explained the material thoroughly. I honestly recommend having her for your physics professor, even if it isn't for PHYS040C.
Side note, you really need to know the right hand rule for this class or you're going to suffer second half of the quarter.

Requires a bit of studying, but is ultimately not too difficult. Just pay attention in lecture and watch youtube videos to fill in gaps. Just don't take Monday labs as you will have to go over concepts that are taught in lecture later during the week.

Laura Sales was my professor. Very good teaching style, explains things well and does examples in class. Midterm is free response and multiple choice, while final was all multiple choice. I personally found 40C and 40B easier than 40A.

Took with Becker. I found this class a lot more difficult than 40A and 40B since I wasn't used to a lot of the concepts (I also fell behind so lol dont do that). The curves are gonna sharper since there was no helpful practice midterm or a practice final. But, if you score higher on your final than the midterm, the final replaces your midterm which is great!
Topics are tough so put in extra time to learn the concepts. Try understanding the concepts instead of memorizing as Becker tests more on understanding and applying. Much harder than 40B and 40A.

Took it with Yanou Cui. It was her first time teaching it, so she did not offer any practice exams. I personally wouldn’t take it again with her as I don’t like how she explained things. It seemed like all she did was read off lecture slides from the textbook. Her exam questions were also mostly theoretical instead of working with solid numbers.

Laura Sales was very easygoing during Fall 2020. She offered a modest amount of extra credit too. She really cares about the students learning, and overall, she was definitely one of my favorite professors at UCR so far. 4 exams total, each 5 multiple choice questions, and she drops the lowest score. If you're taking EE001A at the same time, you'll see a lot of nice overlap.

Professor Sales. SHE IS THE BEST PROFESSOR IN THE DEPARTMENT. Take this class if you are a non-physics major and would just like a class on physics taught in a casual, chill way. You will definitely learn from her class, and she is a great teacher. But she is also a practical person, and understands that not every one of her students wants to dedicate their entire lives around learning physics.
This class was made unnecessarily hard online, only 1 lecture a week (fall 2020),  a bunch of useless videos and a garbage textbook, if you have prior physics knowledge it is not that hard

dont do it with becker, he spends all of lecture rambling and not even half the class understands what hes saying. also he worries way more abt catching cheaters than making sure students understand material.

It's being taught by Anson (Dr. D'Aloisio) and Dr. Long.

 Anson's part was supposed to be easy. Daily reading quizzes are fair and homework and quizzes are fairly easy (and fair lol). The midterm will kill a great portion of the class. Since it was his first time teaching a lot of us were unprepared for the difficulty of the midterm, but aside from that the material itself is okay (you will need to sit and think about it though).

Quantum physics (2nd half) hurts. It makes no sense, and everything is counterintuitive. The textbook is exceedingly complicated and the homework problems are often never going to show on quizzes or the final (a few essential ones did but you will be able to tell what those are). By the way, Dr. Long's quizzes and final are based almost entirely on lecture notes (which he posts), but if you are cool with going to lecture, do so from time to time as sometimes some of the things he says reflects what you could see on a quiz.


The math gets so complicated you will need to use Mathematica. You literally only do that so you can get homework points smh. This class will force you to constantly ask the most fundamental of questions only for you to still be confused. Good luck!

Thermal physics isn't an easy topic, but Zandi teaches the topic alright. Homework are textbook problems, which you should understand. Midterm was basically homework problems/ lecture notes (very fair). Final identical to homework problems/ lecture noes (very fair). Ask her to give you a practice midterm/final and she'll provide you one.

description: ADVANCED STATISTICAL PHYSICS AND FIELD THEORY
SEMINAR IN GENETICS, GENOMICS, AND BIOINFORMATICS
A COLLOQUIUM ON THE PRINCIPLES OF PLANT PATHOLOGY

comments.comment: I had Professor Godrej, and grades were based only on a midterm, a final, and discussion. She is a fantastic lecturer and speaks very clearly. Her voice is gorgeous and she made the material easy to understand. The average on the midterm was a 78. She lets you make your own cheat sheet for it, too. I got a 99 on the midterm and the final was optional (thanks Corona) so I got an A+.

i had prof godrej. theres a lott of notes you will take. tbh you dont need to buy the books cuz its hellaa $$, just make sure u go to the lectures bc her lectures r very dense and will help you the most for midterms/final. shes a rlly good lecturer and answers all the questions she gets, but sometimes she talks too fast and the info can be a lil difficult. i studied using the notes i took from her lectures and ended with an A.
Took with Prof Busacca.  Short answer essays on midterms and multiple papers.  No final, at least for my quarter.  Easy as long as you get a easy-ish TA grader and pay attention in class.

Had Gabe for Fall 2019, he was pretty funny and passionate and knowledgeable about the subject. There were a LOT of readings, like way too much and for one of the midterms, everyone basically bombed it but he curved it so most people passed. He won't be teaching winter 2020 so idk about the other teacher but this class pretty interesting if you like politics, if not, it is probably gonna be very boring for you.

Easy A. I highly recommend you read the assigned reading. 2 midterms, one final. The tests  compose of multiple choice, fill in the blank and short answers. That may seem a lot, but if you go over the book and lecture slides, it's a breeze. I had Heba Hodaly.
TAKE WITH IREPOGLU CARRERAS. So easy, just a bit boring but def an easy pass, and an easy A with minimal effort. Provides extra credit opportunities.
Irepoglu-Carreras is the best! If you can choose, take it with her.

Irrepoglu-Carreras talks way too much; you don't need to write down everything she says. The 2 exams/final and notes are based on the slides/study guides. Reading the textbook helps to clarify the slides but you definitely don't need to do any more than skim the chapters.
If you take this class with prof. Marissa Brookes, it's fairly easy as long as you just show up to lectures and discussion. there's 3 exams + the final exam so one bad grade won't kill you
Prof. D'Anieri knows his stuff. Prof. provides a study guide with the exam questions on it. There are usually 30 questions and 5 will be on the exam. TA's are really picky about the answers
Had Brookes, her exams were hard since they were fill in the blanks and she wanted you to be very specific about things.
I had Brookes, the class was awfully boring and the exams were hard since they were all fill in the blank. The TAs were strict on grading and wanted you to be overly specific.
I would stay clear of Professor D’anieri, it’s not that the material was difficult but the sheer amount of reading and relatively broad study guides made the class a big pain.

Paul D’Anieri is extremely helpful in office hours, intelligent, kind, and has damn good music taste. DO THE READING. you have to know a lot of concepts and how to make a good argument. Overall a great and eye-opening class, just s lot of work

Took it with Paul D’Anieri. He knows what he’s talking about, and is a great lecturer. His office hours help so much and he’s overall just a cool guy. Into music, always plays a song in the beginning of class. A lot of reading, but he wrote the textbook and it’s pretty good. As long as you know the concepts you should be okay. Two midterms and a final. Each midterm has five short answer questions and an essay for 50 minutes, which isn’t as bad as it sounds. The final has the same layout but with an extra essay and 25 more minutes. Loved the class!
no homework or papers, the test were difficult because of the time constraints (50 mins)

Took Irrepoglu-Carreras over Fall 2020 quarter, attendance wasn't required (even in her live session).  Ridiculously easy, her quizzes are graded by completion, not performance, you can just speed run through the quiz and still get 100%.  Her mid-term and final was open book and was not proctored, both were extremely easy.  The class only gets difficult if you have a TA that assigns quizzes on the readings every week, I got lucky and got a chill ass TA (she never assigned quizzes).  Shout out to Bea-Sim!

Professor Irrepoglu-Carreras made course very easy. Grading is based on bi-weekly quizzes that are participation based and 2 take-home exams. All course presentations and materials were easily available. Vocabulary heavy course, but easy to understand.

I had professor irepoglu-carreras and she was really great! there's biweekly quizzes but they're only participation based and don't effect your grade. the midterm and final are take-home and aren't very hard at all, most of the answers you can find in her lectures. other than that, there's readings every week, but they're usually like no more than 12 pages and are pretty interesting!
Irepoglu-Carreras is the best professor! Take it with her if you have the choice!

description: POLITICS OF RACE, IMMIGRATION, AND ETHNICITY IN THE UNITED STATES

comments.comment: Professor Mannies was cool a lot of opportunities for extra credit

description: THEORY AND METHODOLOGY OF POLITICAL SCIENCE

comments.comment: Taken with Diogo Ferrari. Was a weird class since he teaches weirdly. Covers a lot of topics and ground. He was a bit frusturating at times since he would not answer questions directly, but the TA was amazing. Exams were similar to psets but asked for more analysis. Attendance was a factor

Taken with Ferrari. Hard course with a lot of theoretical concepts. He explains the concepts, but NEVER shows you how to actually apply them. If i did not have my TA, I would have failed. Midterm/Final are always curved because of how people perform. Most either do really well or fail

Yasemin Irepoglu Carreras taught the class. Tests were very easy. Class had a Midterm, Final, 6-8 page term paper, class participation (random activities), and discussion. No textbook and weekly readings are not really required. Term/vocab heavy.

description: UNITED STATES FOREIGN POLICY SINCE WORLD WAR II

comments.comment: Jeremy Busacca taught the class. 80% of the class was based on 3 essays. Reading heavy. Teaching style is very freestyle. Id say many in the class are split between hating his style and loving it.

description: THE POLITICS OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE, FINANCE, AND DEVELOPMENT

comments.comment: Taken with Professor Bishin. Super intresting lectures - hes a fun dude who really wants you to learn. Extra credit pop quizes. Take as many classes with him as possible. I learned more with Bishin than any other lower-div courses
Professor Merolla taught the class. Lots of assignmnets and group work. She is very helpful and approachable.

description: HUMAN RIGHTS IN THEORY, LAW, AND POLITICS
GOVERNMENT AND POLITICS IN WESTERN EUROPE

comments.comment: Taken with Pererya-Johnston. Very straightfoward class with 2 exams and a paper. Only slighly annoying thing is that discussion section attendance was mandatory

description: LATIN AMERICA:  THE QUEST FOR DEVELOPMENT AND DEMOCRACY

comments.comment: Taken with Noel Johnston. Simple asynchronous class with a lot of application of theoretical concepts. It can be tough, but the concepts themselves are broken down very well. Midterm's and Finals are very fair and require a lot of application. Some extra credit opportunities are available

description: SOCIAL SCIENCE, HISTORY, AND QUALITATIVE METHODOLOGY

comments.comment: He gives you most of the answers to the test questions every lecture. So I got a B just by studying all the test questions he gave us. Never went to lecture.

Steve Clark is an amazing professor. I didnt even open the book for my two midterms and got an A and a B. Just go to his lectures, a lot of the quiz content is about his anecdotal examples. 10/10 would take again
Rosenbaum is a gem. Easy A. Gives you 20/25 exam questions ahead of time
Very easy for people who aren’t into psychology. Highly recommend taking it for a requirement.

Huffman is amazing at explaining the material and really funny, definitely take it with her if possible. Everything is based on the notes, don't waste time buying the textbook. You'll definitely have to do some studying but most of it is easy

Took it with Dr. Huffman. Good professor especially if you are desiring to take more PSYCH classes. Reading the textbook isn't super super important, so you can probably get away with not reading it because she mentions how theres only like two to three questions on the exam where the information comes from the book. Key to doing well in the class is memorization and understanding the notes she post on iLearn. Lecture is important to as she says things that rewards those students who attend lecture, but can get from a friend. Got a B+ and read the book and went to lecture, but beware of the Neuroscience part, required a lot of memorization but is doable. Note... on her power point there are presenter notes when you download them... OPEN THOSE and study those too.. questions from midterms and final were from there I vividly remember that.

Had Dr. Huffman. There was 2 midterms and they were mostly from lecture slides and a few extra credit questions from the random things that she talks in lectures. You don't really need the textbook since the exams are mostly from lectures

Take this with Huffman. She's funny and actually made me want to come to lecture. Studying required a bit but you can pass without using the textbook at all. Write down some of the weird stuff she says in class, they come up on the test.
prof huffman: easy to get a B, hard to get an A

If you took AP Psych in high school, it is basically a review of that. I never went to class or studied and got a B. I had Dr. Huffman, she's really kind. There's no homework but there are pretty much quizzes every discussion and 2 midterms and a final that make up your grade. Also, she drops the 2 lowest quiz scores

Took it with Professor Steven Clark. Always attend lectures because his exams focus more on what he discusses in class than the book. He posts his slides but they are extremely vague, so it won't be that helpful if you don't pay attention in class.
Easy A with Rosenbaum

took it in the summer with Dr. Huffman, intense 5 weeks. 9 quizzes (lowest one dropped), 1 midterm (average was 87% - 80 multiple choice questions, no backtracking), 1 final exam (80 multiple choice questions, non-cumulative), discussion attendance is mandatory for points, and some zaps & inquiztive assignments weekly. The whole course was on canvas, each week was posted in advance, no required live lecture meetings!
Took it with Huffman. I think overall, it was decently easy. If you followed the textbook, read what you needed to, you could ace the exams. Recommend

Had this class online with Professor Ditta and would highly recommend. She is very passionate about what she teaches, and offers a bunch of extra credit. The assignments themselves are not very difficult. There are weekly assignments for discussion section, and lecture attendance is not mandatory.

Professor Ditta is the best! She made the class flexible and very straightforward. There was 1 final, weekly assignments that are pretty easy, and extra credit quizzes. I'm really going to miss her class because she's just so kind and you can tell she enjoys teaching. Overall, an amazing class!!!

Took this class because everyone said it was easy but I almost failed. I took it with Professor Clark. He was very nice but I just couldn't stay engaged during lectures. His lectures also don't have words with bullet points so it's mostly just listening, which makes it hard for me. He is very approachable and willing to help so that is nice.

Taken with Ditta in Fall 2020. Extremely chill online zoom lectures which I RECOMMEND TAKING NOTES ON (it'll help for the PSYC 001 study guide she releases a week or two before the final). I 100% RECOMMEND DITTA... EXTREMELY HELPFUL AND WANTS TO HELP YOU LEARN THE MATERIAL...LOVES TALKING WITH STUDENTS ABOUT VIDEO GAMES, OTHER TOPICS OUTSIDE OF CLASS AND IN OFFICE HOURS. She gives no midterm as well, only the final, and there are weekly assignments as well as a final project. On another note, she requires 4 hours of "research participation", which is done online. The research consists mostly of taking online quizzes that are used in UCR studies and each one is worth an hour, so do 4 quizzes on the UCR research site for easy completion.

took online with professor ditta, she's great at teaching the material and gives you everything you need to succeed in the class. 1 midterm, 1 cumulative final & a final media project, all free response but it's open note/textbook. there are also lots of extra credit quiz opportunities!

Took this class Winter 2021 with Professor Ditta! AMAZINGGGG PROFESSOR I highly recommend her! She kept online lectures interesting and fun, & also provides a synchronous or asynchronous option for her students. The workload was not hard at all and the midterm and final was easy if you just watch the lectures. She is super organized so it made things so easy. Chapter in the textbook every week (although you don't really have to but the textbook is super interactive so it was very easy to read), Quizzes for every chapter (but you can just keep going till you get 100%, questions are unlimited), and then an assignment every week (but it was lowk busy work, only takes about 20 minutes). At the beginning of the week she also sends out what should be done for the week which is superrr helpful. Oh and media project at the end (I just did a tiktok and got a 102%, super easy) and UCR research hours (just participate in a study) Take this class!!! You'll enjoy it. Got an A+

Rosenbaum gives you all the answers in the lectures and in the reading. He is so adorable and sweet. He makes me laugh and makes it interesting. Make sure to go to every lecture and participate in every discussion if you want points. Hunter the discussion TA is really nice. Don't miss the midterm or the exam or you will have to write a paper.

I took PSYC1 with Professor Ditta. She's really nice and tries hard to make the class engaging. It's pretty easy to get an A if you put in a little effort. Most of my friends and I ended with a 100%. The main assignments are a midterm, final, and a project. There are also discussion activities and weekly "quizzes," that you can take until you get a 100%. 

This class is basically just about putting in effort and it's pretty interesting!
Easier than PSYCH001 imo
Its an ipen notes class
Extremely easy if taught by Prof. Sy. Barely went to lecture and passed with an A
Pretty easy, especially if you have  Dr. Rachel Wu. She does an amazing job breaking everything down. Don't really need the textbook because all of her tests/quizzes are based on the slides!
professor murray makes it fun and interesting, lots of EC opportunities in class but has clickers (20%) also in class, 4 exams each 20%
You are required to go to discussion like 25% of your grade depends on this...
Taken with Barton. Easiest of the series, most people will do better than they did in A and B. No curve, but tests are very fair.

Took with Rachel Wu. Really easy class. Quizzes can be taken twice, no midterm, final is online and open note. Assigned homework is minimal, just 3 simple newspaper article assignments throughout the quarter. Discussion section attendance part of grade. Go to lecture, read the textbook.

Had it with Professor Davis Spring 2020 and she is so nice. My TA was also amazing - Pamela Sheffler. Only thing you need to do to ace the class is memorize the slides. 4 exams, the lowest one gets dropped so if you're satisfied with your grade you don't need to take the "final".

I had Danielle Delany in summer session A for psych. She was super nice and easy-going. Her lectures were easy to understand. The tests were pretty much about the material covered in lecture. If you have her just make sure you know the lecture slides and you'll pass.

Took it with Prof SETO during online format and it was horrible to say the least. His exams required deep understanding of the material which he did not equip us for. I aced phys2A/B but I struggled with his teaching method in 2C. A lot of people would agree he could do MORE examples similar to what he would expect from us and just overall put more effort. I ended up with a B+ so its "do-able"

HELLA easy if you take this class with Professor Sy. Took this class during Fall 2020(online b/c of covid) and he only had 2 lectures live and made the rest of them asynchronous. Just keep up with watching the lectures(like 2 per week) and use the notes you take from them to fill out the study guides he sends out before the exams and you are guaranteed an A on the exams. Exams including the final were non-cumulative and open note + open textbook. Also, go to discussion because they take attendance and it counts towards your grade quite a bit.

I had Prof. Wu for PSYC002 during online classes. All of the lectures, quizzes, and exams are asynchronous, so it's super helpful to go at your own pace. My advice to make sure you don't procrastinate because it WILL screw you over in the end. Make sure you watch the lecture videos and attend the discussion and you'll be fine. I finished with an A.
