I took PSYC2 with Professor Sy. Honestly, I would recommend if you just want an A. I feel that I didn't learn a ton, but the class was really easy. All the tests were multiple choice and open book. The professor is also super nice and upbeat. There wasn't much homework, just reading, which I guess was optional. The textbook is a little boring, but hey, it's free!
Take with professor psy because he makes course easy

Took it with Coulombe. She talks really fast, but she makes the content pretty easy. If you took AP Stat, you're chill, but if you're not good with stat, you might need more practice. It's pretty straightforward except for the last two weeks (It's a little confusing, but still okay). Somewhat of an easy A if you pay attention tbh

Take with Dr. Annie Ditta if at all possible! She is overall extremely nice and understanding, and allows a cheatsheet (front and back of one paper) for exams. She also breaks down the concepts super simply and goes fairly slow/thorough to make sure everyone understands. Just understand the basic concepts/write down the differences between the types of tests for exams and you'll be fine.
Take with Prof. Natsuaki- makes sure you understand material and TA's pretty good

Took it with Duyen Trang. If you took AP stats in high school, then you'll be fine. If you didn't, Duyen does a great job at showing how to do it in a neat and easy way to understand. 2 midterms and 1 cumulative final - all open notes - that are open for several days for you to complete. About 3-4 homeworks are due before each midterm/final that are graded based on completion. Duyen also holds review section a day before each exam. Attend those because she goes over the study guide and it really helps.

Very math intensive. However, Natsuaki made this class pretty okay. I've never taken stats and I did fairly okay. Conceptually, it gets a little iffy at time and oh boy, the calculations are endless but not overall a super hard class. Lectures a bit boring but would recommend with Natsuaki overall.

Took it with Natsuaki in Fall (Online). Honestly stats was really scary going into this but I came out loving the subject. The course is vigorous so carry your weight and you’ll do well. Also don’t be afraid to go to office hours for your TA since they do all your grading. We had 3 midterms and  a cumulative final. Also one paper and 2 weekly assignments. Like I said it’s vigorous but it’s not innately hard. Discussions were not mandatory except the last one to show a portfolio (another assignment). I would definitely invest in an iPad or a tablet so you can hand write upload your homework and test work easily. It saves a lot of time during exams. Exams were not proctored but make sure you show your work.
Take over the summer so you don't have to complete 2+ research papers.

Took it with Prof Franchak. The textbook comes with inquizitive so make sure to do those assignments for easy points. 3 midterms and 1 cumulative final. Study his slides and take the practice quizzes and you should do fine. Grade is split 50/50 between lecture and lab (aka research papers) papers are most important ask your TAs for help and don’t procrastinate those

I had Prof. Ditta and she was honestly one of my favorite professors I’ve had. She allows a 1-paged (front&back) cheat sheet on all exams and allows test corrections to get points back on midterms. She is genuinely super helpful and wants her students to succeed.

Dr. Calanchini is a great professor and a very understanding person. He's great at applying concepts to relatable/funny real-life examples. Overall the material itself is easy, there's just kind of a lot of it. He does a "midterm" every 2 weeks (5 total, 20 questions each) which sounds awful but it makes the class way easier because you only have to memorize 2 weeks worth of material at a time rather than 5. They're usually pretty easy, and at least for Spring 2020 (online/during the pandemic), they were all open book/open notes. Usually there are 2 research proposals throughout the quarter but for Spring 2020 there was only 1. Either way, don't get behind on it! Also, DO THE INQUIZITIVES. They are basically practice for his "midterms"/final.

Took this online during Spring 2020. Dr. Calanchini is an awesome instructor and also very nice/pretty lenient. The material itself isn't hard but there is a LOT of work, mainly because of the research proposal project.

Dr. Franchak was good professor. I enjoyed his lectures that would often have a bit of humor embedded within. There was a lot of content that was covered, but Dr. Franchak did a great job of organizing how the content was taught. I appreciated his willingness to be lenient on assignment due dates. He explained everything well and gave plenty of opportunities for students to improve their grades. Everything was on quizlet pretty much (Online Spring Quarter 2020 btw).

This class was actually pretty nice. For a 6 unit class during Spring of 2020, it was manageable. The Prof (Franchak) was SUPER understanding of the events that were happening at the time. Just off of how lenient he was and understanding of how people were dealing with things (1 paper instead of the usual 2, dropped lowest test, very communicative) during those times, I would recommend.

Took with prof Franchak, he posts the lecture on Yuja. He is a great professor, there are 5 quizzes, final is a quiz as well. The quizzes are open note but you still need to know the material to answer the short answer questions. There is one 6 page research paper, but the discussion assignments help with it.

Psychology of Creativity: Professor Ditta is probably one of the best professors ever. She really prioritizes the learning and understanding of her students in terms of making her lectures very engaging by adding activities that help you understand the concepts. She has weekly quizzes that give you a sense of how she writes her exam questions which I find very useful. There are 2 midterms and 1 Final project (no final exam).

Annie Ditta was the professor and she was a new professor to UCR. She makes the class so engaging and brings in interesting guest lecturers. Exams are extremely easy if you just simply memorize the content/ use common sense. There's a project at the end of the class, it's very simple practically everyone gets 100s. Just make sure to show up to every discussion.

My professor was Dr. Abdulrazak. The class has a lot of information to remember, which made it difficult. Just read the lecture slides and textbook. There are 3 tests in total (“final” is not cumulative). Tests are fair, nothing too tricky. Average is usually ~76%. Also, there are 3 pop quizzes given in lecture so be sure to always attend class.

Dr. Peter Hickmott is amazing and uploads all the slides. Tests are totally based on lecture slides and it isn't that big of a deal if you miss some classes (attendance isn't taken), but he explains concepts really well and it's easier to study if you attend lecture. It's kind of a lot of work because there is a lot of material to study, but most of the concepts themselves aren't very hard and the class is enjoyable overall.

I had Dr. Hickmott. Two midterms, one final, no homework. This is a very difficult class, but his passion for the material and teaching puts the course in a propitious perspective. Best advice is ALWAYS stay on top of the material, especially if you're a neuroscience major!!! The exams cover lecture/discussion material, so attend both. He doesn't try to trick you - everything is straight forward - but do pay attention to the greater details.
Korzus’s exams were super hard for no reason. The exams were nothing like the study guide.

description: CELLULAR NEUROSCIENCE: MEMBRANE AND SYNAPTIC PHENOMENA
COMPUTATIONAL NEUROSCIENCE LABORATORY: INTRODUCTION TO BRAIN MODELING TECHNIQUES

comments.comment: Don't take this class with Daniel Ross. Even though he apparently was nice during previous quarters, he suddenly got pretty unaccommodating during Fall 2020 when I took this class. He also did things like give us a bunch of things due at one time during finals week when we were all stressed out. He also wasn't very considerate of COVID messing with our time/money. Unlike most other professors, those of us who had to get a job/extra jobs during school because of the pandemic weren't accommodated in terms of participation we had to miss (and it was 25% of final grade). He was also really inconsiderate about money, for example he said that a $50 2nd textbook cost couldn't be waived but it's "just a fraction of your tuition anyway" (he also mentioned during this announcement that people told him they were struggling to afford food/rent and he basically responded with "That sucks but I can't do anything about it," it was unbelievable). The topics in the class were fairly interesting but Daniel completely ruined it for basically everyone in the class.
Burgess. He expects a lot of class participation. There's a 15 page paper at the end.

Dr. Julia Revord is one of the nicest professors I've ever taken. She is super accommodating and taught the class really well. Lectures were asynchronous for the quarter I took it but honestly most of us only watched like 1 or 2 lectures and did fine, especially because it was all open-note/open book. No homework. Just some short multiple choice tests (20 questions) every so often, and the lowest one is dropped for your final grade. The topic is kind of interesting too. Highly recommend

Took this with Prof Hughes. Definitely take it with him if you can. He made the concepts easy to understand. Take notes and you’ll do well on the exams. Three 20 question midterms and a final and a short reflection paper. Best class
easily the hardest class I've taken, test wise. Professor words exams VERYYY intricately and throws in the most ridiculous small-detailed concepts into tricky exam questions. Be aware!!

Took it with Pamela Sheffler and it was such an interesting class! You learn about the development of people throughout the lifespan, which is pretty straightforward and quite insightful. There was 1 midterm, 1 group presentation, a final project (paper), and a final exam. It may seem like a lot of work, but it really reinforced my learning.

description: THE CULTURAL BASES OF HUMAN DEVELOPMENT

comments.comment: SPRING 2021 - Professor Melissa Wilson - Super interesting and easygoing class. The exams are basically just lecture material with a little bit of questions where you apply certain concepts to specific scenarios. 1 essay that is pretty easy because most TAs are really nice and helpful. 1 final, 4 "mini-exams," and reading quizzes.

description: COVID 19 Pandemic: Life, Adaptation and Mental Health

comments.comment: Dr. Rosenbaum made the class easy but the material itself was complicated. Interesting class but you need to go to lecture if you want an A.

description: PROSEMINAR ON CURRENT RESEARCH IN COGNITIVE PSYCHOLOGY
PROSEMINAR ON CURRENT RESEARCH IN DEVELOPMENTAL PSYCHOLOGY
PROSEMINAR ON CURRENT RESEARCH IN SOCIAL/PERSONALITY PSYCHOLOGY
Diversity & Inequality Psychology Proseminar: Implicit Bias, Stigma, and Microaggression

comments.comment: I had professor Bruce Babcock. He's pretty cool, slightly unorganized. But if you go to lecture and do the 3 assignments, you'll be just fine. If you're interested in government you should have no problem taking interest into this class and getting a good grade. Readings not necessary

Took with Prof Babcock. Attend lectures and you'll be fine. Exams are fair and easy. Weekly readings but he goes over it during lectures so you don't really have to do them. 2 midterms and a cumulative final.

Honestly read the book before you attend lecture and really try to listen to professor Ramakrishnan. Doing all that reading and cramming the night before your Policy Brief, final, and midterm really isn't it, so get on top of it. Also T.A.'s will give you a long list of things to study, but like only a quarter of those things will be on the test. I barely attended lecture and I studied the night before my finals. Passed the class with a B+.
Taken with Babcock. Easy class somewhat tedious assingmnets.

prof brady fall 2020: exams & first two writing assignments were dumb easy, third 2000 word assignment should be ok if you don't procrastinate. dr. brady's really nice and although he's not v flexible for individuals he did make the final optional and promise a curve

Taken online with Professor Serieux-Lubin. Professor was extremely uninvolved, most interaction was through the TA. Never started anything before the day it was due in this class & got an A easily. 

-3 Written assignments (~200, 800, 2000 words)
-Exam every 2 week on 2 weeks of material that you learn from videos + linked readings. Used to be 2 short answer + multiple choice, was just multiple choice by the end of the quarter
-attendance taken once a week from discussion with the TA
-plenty of extra credit offered via discussion boards/submitting early drafts of written assignments

Took it with Brady and Babcock Spring 2021. Please avoid this class if you are a stem major as it will get in your way of focusing on your major classes. I have a few complaints. 1. There is a lot of reading. They are mostly 5-10pg articles and they average about 7 different articles A WEEK. The exams are reading heavy so you have to read the articles to do well. 2. The TAs are absolutely useless. It sucks enough that all lectures are recorded so you have no contact with the professor. My TA took an average of 1 week to respond to my emails, which would be too late anyway. The only actual class time is during discussion and most of the TAs for this class will straight up say to not ask them about the material because they don't have time to look at it. For exams, they tell you to do the reading, give you a study guide of what they think will be on the exam and call it a day. 2. There are 4 midterms and 1 final exam. Basically, there is an exam every other week on Fridays, so be careful about what classes you might have on Fridays. 4. The assignments are tedious and boring and the TAs grade harshly for things like citations, grammar, word count, etc. If you go over or under the word requirement, you will get points deducted. 5. The professors are not empathetic. A peer of mine got sick with covid and was in the hospital. When they let the professor know since they missed an assignment, the professor said that they should have told him sooner and the student received a 0 on the assignment. Good things about the course: 1. open-note exams 2. recorded lectures if that's your thing 3. Sometimes curves exam scores. 4. They drop your lowest exam score. (somehow got an A, but still. Good luck lol)

I took this class online, for spring quarter in 2021, because I had read some threads recommending this class. This class is basically Busywork: The Class, and I would strongly, STRONGLY advise against taking this class if you don't need to. I took this class for credits, and the amount of time I had to put into this class was ridiculous. I ended up having to put more time in this class than the other two classes I took this quarter combined. The grading for this class is based around biweekly exams (that's 5 exams total - 5!!) that are open-book, but because they are open-book, the professor takes that as an excuse to grill you on minute details of the readings assigned for that week. Readings are pretty lengthy, and on top of doing readings as well as studying for each of the 5 exams, you are also given writing assignments that progressively get longer on creating your own public policy. I did fine on these writing assignments, as well as the exams. It feels like you only have to do the bare minimum to succeed in this class, but the bare minimum is still a ridiculous amount of time.

Took with Prof Brint. Group/partner discussions every lecture. Pop quizzes every week. 1 midterm and final. Interesting class and enjoyable. Quizzes & TA can make or break your grade. Optional debates that you can do but it is limited and assigned during the first lecture.

Taken with Professor Brint. Excellent teaching methods. Sometimes a bit slow on getting to the point. Class not difficult. Optional debates that can be substited for Midterm/Policy Report. Decently easy.
Relatively easy class, usually taught by Dr. Brint. Just study the slides and it is an easy A.
Took it with Prof Vergara-Tapia, class content was interesting and straightforward. There is a midterm and a final, and weekly quizzes. Most test questions come from lecture
Easy class - completetly asynrchronous. Taken with Serieux-Lubin. Super easy midterm and papers. Easy/Free A basically
Took it with Prof Serieux Lubin, she was really understanding and kind. The class is 2 papers, 4 discussion posts, a midterm and final. The test questions are straight from lecture too. Great class.
Class wasn't too hard, took it with Prof Seriuex Lubin during Fall 2020 so it was online and asynchronous. Open note midterm and final. She gives a lot of opportunity for extra credit near the end.
Very easy! 2 policy briefs that were short (minimum 500 words) and the TA was lenient.
serieux-lubin winter 2021: so, so many extra credit opportunities. really don't have to read anything, although the readings are pretty interesting in their own right

Taken with Brady. Nice class a lot of application of sociological concepts and ideas. A lot of reading but the class is completely doable. Super nice and curves exams. Make sure you read/skim read for the exams - completely fair!

description: WATER ECONOMICS, MANAGEMENT AND POLICY: CALIFORNIA AND BEYOND

comments.comment: Taken with Newman. Super easy class consisting of reading quizzes. You dont really need to read the readings - just need to know how to skim the content appropriately. Besides that a short paper and attendance and thats all. Super accomodating and very good class

description: STATE GOVERNMENTS AS LABORATORIES OF CHANGE
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IN UNITED STATES CITIES

comments.comment: avoid prof oh. hes super unprepared for lectures and has a somewhat heavy accent, reading helps with the pop quizzes but you can easily just google his study guides for the midterm and final, essays are pretty easy and weekly discussion posts are easy points

took it with Dr. Isaac this quarter, at first I was reluctant but this was my easiest class this quarter. He gave us the midterm verbatim and plans to do the same with the final. Our only assignment was an essay in which it was basically just a writing exercise because he gave us questions to answer. Overall a great class and professor.

Prof Issac will lecture forever but as long as you study the study guides you will pass the class easily. one midterm one final and an essay. don't need to go to lectures if you do the readings... overall not a very difficult class just make sure to do well on the exams.

if new teacher, professor Isaac moise from UCLA, easy class, 2 exams 25% each, final 6 page essay worth 20% rest is just participation/attendance, and the study guides were word for word the exam questions, show up to lecture, he would give us important information that only he would give to the 40 or so people who showed up to the entire lecture hall. difficulty 3/10
Online, 2 written assignments a week(easy), 1 quiz a week. 1 research paper no midterms
Took with Alexander Michael, easy class. 4 books to read, 2 essays. Midterm and final was easy.

Took Alexander Michael, extremely easy class with a chill professor.  Lecture did not have mandatory attendance, but discussion section does (you won't have to worry about your grade if you actively participate in discussion).  Quizzes are given out weekly and contain 3-5 questions, it was multiple choice and you have three chances to get 100%.  I never read any of the books assigned and still maintained a 100% average on the quizzes (download the pdf and CTRL+F key words).  Our midterm and final were papers on the book you chose to read, prompt was easy and open-ended enough to read a few pages to get an A.

description: JAINISM: AN INDIAN RELIGION OF NON-VIOLENCE
WOMEN'S ISSUES IN MODERN MUSLIM THOUGHT
PUBLIC RELIGIOUS DISCOURSES IN MODERN ISLAM

comments.comment: Only take with professor simmons

Honestly if you put some effort in you should get an A pretty easily. Had San Juanita Garcia, tests were straightforward, but she's a bit unorganized. Just review slides or read the textbook and you'll be fine.

Really easy class. Garcia just kinda reads off her slides and goes really fast so be prepared for that. The textbook will be needed but only minimally; tests are based mostly on lecture notes and you'll get a study guide before each

Simmers is an awesome professor. Tells great stories. Threw a haymaker on the second midterm, but there are a couple of extra credit opportunities for discussion and doing the bonus synthesis (only if you did the first 5 synthesis activities). Final was noncumulative

Took it with Professor Simmons. Don't underestimate Sociology. READ the textbook, as it is where most of the information for the course comes from. Easy C if you just review the google docs before the midterms, but if you want a B or an A, you need to read and actually know the concepts as her test were not definition based but were more conceptual in terms of applying your knowledge to real life examples and context.  I got a B, and I read every chapter and attended all the lectures. She is funny AF, so thats always a positive of attending lecture. Does not post lecture slides, but can get them if you make friends. Otherwise a good and insightful class to take, but reading is required for a good grade.

Jennifer Summers is great. Extra credit just from doing all 6 synthesis activities and going to discussion. Got an A on the first midterm and was able to slack off on the second midterm and final and still got an A.

Took with San Garcia. Extremely nice and inspiring. Class is really easy and you don't need to buy the textbook since she uploads the lecture slides with the information you need for the exams. Make sure to do the packback on time since it's worth like 10% of your grade. Your TA can make or break your grade.

The lecturer is amazing. I could listen to her read off a phone book, but the course requires 3 midterms based off of 100 pages of reading each. It's just more work than I wanted to put in for what was supposed to be my "easy" class.

Schmitt’s both lecture & reading heavy for his course! Exams are lengthy & heavily worded so it’s quite neck breaking if you need to understand a question clearly. For an introductory class, it’s much more challenging & in depth than most. Study double the time & make your own charts to balance his lectures & readings!

Don't take Christopher Schmitt!! He gave a 2 day midterm, one was written answers and then multiple choice. The final was 100 questions multiple choice, although he told us we might have a written just to mess with our minds a little more. :) His lectures are unorganized and not helpful at all (he writes a few words on the slides and talks about random life experiences he had which he tries to relate to the class) and he makes us read random chapters in the textbook instead of just in order. Typos and confusing questions were a regular occurrence in his midterm and final. Hard final and it was 45% of grade while midterm was 40%. Anyone saying it was easy or a good class is a liar. Coming from someone who got almost 100% on that hard midterm.
The exams were difficult. They were mostly lecture based but the format of the the questions were overall hard. The readings were not all that hard and the professor gave a lot of exam hints.
the way professor schmitt taught was odd. there were no notes to write down. you had to catch everything he said as you never know what would really be on the quizzes and exams

professor schmitt makes this class unnecessarily hard, but if you do take him get ready to study everything: lecture notes, textbook, and videos he shows in class. the final was really hard compared to the midterm.

I had Rotondi, it was extremely difficult for an intro class. the class itself isn't bad, it's just him. he's a great lecturer and funny guy. there are 2 midterms, a final and a paper (which is basically the easiest assignment we got). however, his tests are extremely tedious. he over complicates the questions, and it's mainly based on readings (which are extremely heavy). class is interesting, exams and readings are unnecessarily hard for an INTRO class.
If u get prof. Rotondi, then drop it. He made the class way too hard. It is an intro class but didn't feel like an intro with him. He made the class way too hard.

Took it online with Prof Janet Hill, class material in itself wasn't too hard. Midterm and final questions come from lectures, readings, and videos/films. Don't know if it was because it was online, but it felt like the class required a lot of work for a lower div.

Not a difficult class but avoid Dr Hill if you get the chance. Was very vague about the midterm and yelled at me in front of a Zoom lecture of ~250 people when I tried to ask about it. Hard to reach by email and quite stubborn. Very unprofessional.
quizzes every week, rotondi pushed back paper and quizzes (pretty understanding), heavy reading and lots of recorded lectures
Had Rotondi was extremely hard, 120 pages of reading a week, a quiz every week two different books plus about 2-3 hours of lecture videos a week sheesh.

I had Rotondi for Fall 2020 and he made it really difficult for an intro class. The weekly quizzes are insanely specific and are based on 100+ pages. Irrelevant details you don't think are going to be on the quiz, WILL BE ON THE QUIZ. I spent hours studying the readings and worked really hard to get an A, so DO NOT take this class if you have other classes to prioritize. He gave an extra credit quiz but that might have just been because of the circumstances of this quarter. The paper was easy because the TAs are pretty lenient. You can not slack in this class, I know many people that failed this course because of his quizzes so be aware.

I had Rotondi for this class (Fall 2020). He’s a great professor. He’s very passionate about his teaching. READ! READ! READ! The class has quizzes and doesn’t have final.You’ll pass the quizzes as long as you read.
Spring 2021 no midterm, or final just weekly 20 point quizzes but they are easy if you do the reading. asynchronous only meet weekly for TA

Very challenging course because there is a lotnof memeorization of theories and terms. However, it was insightful and interesting! I do only recommend this class to Soc majors or people interested in it. I know many people who failed the class...

Tests were all multiple choice based off lecture notes, not reading. Assignments are repetitive and more or less busy work and the last paper was basically a repeat of the first five assignments compiled together. I took it with Prof. Hill and she’s not the best lecturer. Be prepared to listen to her drone on and on about her personal life during class.

Took it with Prof. Perry ( Amy Perry ). She made it an easy class if you attended the lectures, because thats what the 4 quizzes were based off of. If you attend the lectures, you don't have to read because she just talks about it instead. The lowest quiz is dropped.

Took this class with Schmitt, was pretty easy to follow cus it was online. Asynchronous lectures, 1 quiz, non cumulative midterm and final, both multiple choice, & 2 short response papers. The test questions were tricky and hard sometimes, but if u do the readings then it'll be a lot easier
If the professor is Amy Kroska, DO NOT TAKE THE CLASS. She's a terrible professor.
I took this class with Kalousova and it was pretty hard. Go to discussions and put in work, doing homework cost like $120. Not an impossible class but definitely not an easy A

Grade is based on three exams and an 8 page paper, not cumulative. The paper is a research proposal. The study guide is basically the same as the questions on the test. Also, the answers are the same as the notes from the slides.
Some TAs graded the essays much harder than the others.

description: POLITICAL ECONOMY AND GLOBAL SOCIAL CHANGE
ASIAN AMERICAN WOMEN: WRITING THE SELF IN LITERATURE AND FILM

comments.comment: I had Senora Ballester and she’s a very nice professor. She’s very helpful but she teaches at a very fast pace and gives a lot of work. Classes are also mandatory and she makes you show your face on zoom.

Professor Ballester is an AMAZING teacher! At first it seems like she is going really fast but her teaching style is great. I knew NO spanish and can actually understand it very well. Shes always open to giving feedback on homework and compositions so never hesitate to ask if you want that perfect score on your homework. Honestly  wish I could take her for spanish 2 because she ultimately wanted us to have a good understanding of spanish. Lots of class and homework though but pretty easy!
Kind of tedious and annoying. Especially if you have Yolanda Cardenas. Good Professor, but it will require a lot of work from you with an exam one week and a composition the next.

Winter 2021: Antonio Montoya. I’m a non native speaker with 4years of high school spanish (including AP Spanish). Overall the grading is harsh but he does try to make it easy for us to understand. He’s very helpful when it comes to addressing questions or homework. You have to actively participate during Zoom and turn on your camera. He takes attendance. The class consists of using McGraw broken down into 8 sections and everyday (Mon-Thur) the assignment deadline is due the next day before class starts instead of 11:59pm. There’s also chapter quizzes based on the homework and textbook. Two writing compositions during class time. Midterm is an individual oral presentation. I feel like this class was way easier than high school but I tend to forget everything so it was basically a review course but also relearning what I forgot. He wasn’t mean or rude like I hear about the other Spanish professors. The class was chill. Take him if you can! If you know more on speaking Spanish then this class would be easy for you.

Taken during winter 2021. a lot of work and tedious especially if you aren't the best at Spanish. Lots of homework (every night plus studying). Grades somewhat hard for it only being Spanish 2. Attendance is also mandatory plus having your camera on

I took this class with Pedro Garcia Lopez and while he was nice, he was a tough grader and really expects you to get down Spanish. Class has 2 written exams, 5 textbook assignments and quizzes, 2 oral presentations (one for the midterm and one for the final), and a final written exam. However, the textbook assignments/quizzes are 30% of your grade, so do good on those and try to get B's on the other assignments. Be prepared because the quizzes can take a while to complete because of how lengthy the questions are. Plus the textbook was online and terrible (not to mention it was 50 bucks).

If you're taking with Oscar Valle, be ready to teach yourself all of the material. He teaches the class very differently than other TAs so he doesn't really seem like hes organized or has a lesson plan but he's pretty helpful. Spanish 2 concepts were okay, just lots of memorizing and I say if you're a decent spanish speaker and you're able to teach yourself, take him!

It is not too bad, I say 8 just because of the work load. Lots of McGraw Hill homework plus extra assignments by the TA. 2 writing assignments and 2 oral exams just like every spanish class. It is important to know your grammar very well to pass.

If you are a Spanish speaker this is the easiest class basically GPA booster. If you are not a Spanish speaker this class will take a huge amount of time, make sure you practice a lot. If possible try to pair up or be friends with a Spanish speaker. Homework heavy!! professor navarro is honestly so sweet and he really does care, also super funny.

Taken Winter 2021 (COVID-19 Remote Learning). Class is taught entirely by TA/Student Instructor. Heavy reliance on online textbook for homework, quizzes, and final. The online textbook is very specific about what kinds of answers it accepts, so be prepared to go into Office Hours often to fight to get points back. Pretty much daily homework assignments (30 minutes max), 2 short essays, 4 quizzes, two oral assessments (1 presentation, and 1 conversation), and then an online final in the same format as the quizzes/homework. Sounds like a lot, but it is spaced out nicely over the 10 weeks. For my class, cameras were required to be on, which made the class really enjoyable! Nice to interact with people.
Hard grader. Professor Vargas very strict with native speakers, but prepares you well especially if desiring a major/minor in Spanish.

Class is hella easy compared to 109A. Taken with Mirta Copa Vargas and even though the class was hella on her head for being hard, she was not. Her essay topics can be confusing but asking others in the class is key to understanding what to write about. Once you understand her essay prompt/expectations her class is cake. I did essays two days before and walked out with an A.

description: INTRODUCTION TO LITERARY CRITICISM AND ANALYSIS
SEMINAR IN THE LITERATURE OF A SPECIFIC LATIN AMERICAN COUNTRY
STUDIES IN SPANISH LITERATURE AND CULTURE

comments.comment: If you took AP Stats in high school then this class is way too easy. If not, it will require paying closer attention but still not super hard. Took it with Analisa Flores, she's really approachable and helpful. Everything is based on notes and they're easy to understand. No textbook.
Make sure to understand how to use a bit of R programming.

Took with Jill Smith. Never attended lecture, only discussions and labs. The labs honestly teach you with enough to get an idea of what's going on in the class. Easy midterms, but the final is cumulative and a little bit more challenging. Overall easy class.
Class was easy unless you weren't caught up with the material. The last couple of chapters were most challenging throughout the course in my opinion.
Jill Smith is the easiest professor
Jill Smith is a great professor--the class is easy and the averages are usually in the upper 70's.  That being said, don't fall behind on class notes.  There's a few tricky topics.
Professor Analisa is great.

Jill Smith was lecturer, she can be pretty boring but she isn't horrible. The material itself isn't that horrible either but I think it got pretty weird in the end. She posts half written notes online and doesn't post annotated versions so make sure you go to lecture and copy whatever she writes down.
Taken with Flores. Material is relatively easy, but be warned there is a discussion and lab, so be warned that it will require some work.

Took it with Joyce Fu while classes were online. She's extremely sweet and lenient, but not the best professor. I would recommend going to office hours regularly. Overall class was relatively easy, but the first few weeks' worth of material was definitely confusing because of her teaching style. Don't fall behind on the lectures because things start to pick up around weeks 3-4. The midterm, quizzes, and final were pretty ok. She let us have a cheat sheet for both the midterm and final, too.

Spring 2021 - Professor James Flegal - Overall the class was very easygoing and pretty easy. Flegal is a very understanding professor and is open to answering question. Material was pretty easy if you put the effort into learning it. Expect to work with groups every week. Had quizzes called Performance Assessments, which were relatively easy. He provided us with practice performance assessments, midterms, and finals. Many of the practice exams were reflective of the actual exams, so make sure to understand them well.
Super easy. Easier than Dirty 30 and I never even took Stat100A. Professor Cappiello and the TA's are absolute studs. Textbook is also free as a PDF or $20 (new) on amazon.

Dr. Yingzhou Fu (aka Joyce) is to be avoided if at all possible. I only understood her lectures because I learned the topics right before I took the course, otherwise I would've been completely lost like everyone else. The OpenIntro textbook isn't super helpful, I'd recommend looking up YouTube videos to teach yourself.

I took this class with during Yingzhou Fu's first quarter teaching, which make it unsurprising that I was quite lost for the whole quarter. Most people agreed that if not for the TA's in lab and discussion it would've been hard to actually learn. Since it was her first quarter, she made the class pretty easy to pass.

I had Dr. Fu. She was organized but would go off tangent at times so it was hard to follow through with lectures. But the TA's were super helpful and clarified many topics. Midterms weren't too bad, so long as you did the homework. A lot of the questions were from the homework, just different values. Labs were pretty straightforward as well. Just put in a little work and you'll get that A!
Take with Joyce Fu, she allows a sheet of notes on the midterm and final. No curve, but the average score was a B+. It is a lot of information to take in, so be prepared to practice a lot

the ta’s were really good however the course required a certain amount of self studying in order to truly grasp the material. Easy class to get an A but it was only so-so in preparation for other courses

Dr. Linda Penas is very nice and a pretty good instructor, though she has a tendency to just read off of her slides. For Spring 2020 (everything online), she only uploaded lecture slides that had material that would be on the exams (1 midterm, 1 final). There is also a weekly lab using Minitab 19, and it is really easy. The material is mostly just different procedures/concepts of statistics used in business and manufacturing situations to determine quality of products/processes. Equations are WAY easier than in most statistics classes and you are allowed to make a "cheat sheet" for exams so you don't really have to memorize any. DEFINITELY useful for Business majors; a bit less useful for Statistics majors/minors in terms of material we will use someday, but it's good for seeing how to apply statistics in real life.

description: PROBABILITY AND STATISTICS FOR SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING

comments.comment: I had Zhiwei Zhang. Zhang allows us to bring one paper of our own notes to exams. He doesn't curve, but if you have good notes and understand the homework, you shouldn't be struggling that much. The actual content is very easy for the most part. I only seriously looked at the lecture notes the day before exams to make my notes and ended up doing well.

Zhiwei Zhang. Lectures are pretty boring. The professor is pretty monotonous, not everybody can pay attention in those environment. Two midterms, one final. No quizzes in discussion, at least for spring 18. Homework is done on webassign, you can just google the problems if you don't understand. Just another statistics class needed to graduate. I don't understand but just do it it's required. You don't learn too much anyhow.

Not that bad. Took it with Zhang. First midterm was super easy. Second midterm was quite difficult. The final was slightly easier than the second midterm. Homeworks were annoying but doable. 

My advice is get serious after the first midterm.

Professor Zhiwei Zhang. Hard to understand during lectures but is a really nice guy that will always be eager and thorough when answering your e-mails or when you attend his office hours. This class is extremely easy(like Algebra 2 easy) during the first third of it up to and including the first midterm. The content up to the second midterm and final will be noticeably harder(I'd say probably 3-4x as difficult). The key to doing well in this class is doing well on the homework and spending a lot of time on your formula sheet to ensure you have no blind spots in your understanding. The average on the first midterm was 16/20 and the second was 10/20 so you can kind of see what I mean.
I had Jill Smith. It's not as hard as it seems, it just requires a lot of time and energy outside of class that I did not really have.

Had Prof. Smith, class ramps up in difficultly pretty quickly after the first midterm. Probably not the most challenging math course you will ever have but definitely not a walk in the park. Homework is through WebAssign, and is much harder than the exams in my opinion. If you can do the homework well without too much assistance you will do well in the class. Go to office hours and put in a decent amount of time studying for the class and you'll be fine. It also helps if your TA was as helpful as mine, Tyler.
Didn't go to class after the midterm, but still got an A in the class. You'll be alright.

CS Major's Opinion: Took this class with Jill and let me tell your this class will eat you alive if you're not into Math. 

First lets talk about the HW. It's Web Assign with three overall submission tries meaning each try counts for the entire assignment. The HW's are insanely long to do and all pretty much word problems so if you hated those well here they are to fuck you one last time before you graduate. The biggest helpful advice I can give you is to recognize what type of question each problem is asking you and to do each HW before the Quizzes.

The Quizzes themselves are the HW so if you do them before they are due you'll have a fighting chance. A lot of people didn't pick this up until too late. Every discussion ends with a quizz and yeah you get a quizz and HW literally a day before the final. Jill has no mercy.

All in all if you can get 90% and above on the HW's and Quizzes you may just pass this class but it won't be an easy task. THE HW IS HARD. This is a heavy class to balance and if you don't put time and effort into this class you'll definitely repeat it.

The exams and homework were not hard. But the way the class is structured with Shuheng Zhou are what make it frustrating to take. There are no recordings for lectures. No chat during lectures. Which makes it hard to deal with especially for a 3 hour block once a week class.

Probability and Combinatorics are the hardest part of this class. Sometimes differentiating between probability distributions can be tricky but if you keep up, this class will be easy. Make sure to do the HW as this is the most helpful part in ensuring a good grade on tests. Lectures are confusing so reading the book instead is useful. Teacher: Shuheng Zhou
Take it Professor Analisa Flores if you can, she's very organized and fair when it comes to grading and curves. Not a hard class, just hard to keep up with the content as it's a lot.

I had Analisa Flores. Wasn't too bad. Two midterms worth 15% each and a cumulative final worth 30%. Both were curved generously. Study the notes as much as possible and fill them out. Quizzes were worth 15% and are confusing at times, the correct answer choices often didn't make sense. All in all, great professor only thing I wish is that she could've provided us practice exams :(

description: ELEMENTS OF PROBABILITY AND STATISTICAL THEORY

comments.comment: Taught by Flegal for me. He was a horrible teacher and the material was convoluted. Just like 160 A and B, there's at least a whole letter grade curve.
Taught by Esra Kurum - Significantly harder than 170A, but still doable.

Taught by Karen Xu - Senior project class for stats majors. Joke of a class. The professor is teaching how to present, and she's a horrible presenter with stuttering. She doesn't really come prepared to the class. But the class is easy.

description: SOFTWARE TOOLS FOR BIG DATA ANALYSIS

comments.comment: I recommend Professor Bucklin for this class. He is funny, grades easily as long as you put in some effort for your acting, and practically gives you an "A" if you show up to the lecture (participation counts). There is no h.w. for this class. He occasionally gives small quizzes on the plays/screen writes (which can be found online) and write a short review for a play. The final is also super easy (it's a 3-5 min group performance, you get full points for participation).
This class with Buklin was pretty easy. Only 1 midterm, 2 quizzes about easy plays, and no final. He's easy to understand.
Professor Carazo is so cool and the class is fun!

description: PRODUCTION TECHNIQUEST FOR THEATRE, FILM, AND TELEVISION

comments.comment: Annika Speer has fantastic lectures that are entertaining and engaging, absolutely do the readings, they’re not bad and genuinely helped for the midterm. Write your speeches about topics you care about!!

1. Start the reading early and the class should be straight forward. Professor Speer is extremely helpful and engaging in class. Participating in class is useful for feedback that helps with your skills in class. The class is graded mostly by the TA through the speeches, so follow the feedback given.

Michael Bucklin. Easy screenwriting class, I think he said something like 70% of the class get A's so. Mostly effort based rather than actual content based. Lecture, discussion and screening. Screening is one movie per week. Some basic projects but not too much of a time commitment to them to be honest. I just make sure to show up (attendence) and turn in assignments and it'll be pretty difficult to not pass the class. Midterm from the textbook, short answer form. No final, just final project 5-7ish page outline of script.

description: ADVANCED ACTING: ACTING FOR THE CAMERA
SCREENWRITING: REWRITES AND WRITING FOR TELEVISION
